content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Rome: Total War is the most highly acclaimed game in the Total War series. Upon it's launch, it was apparent that the Total War series had something different to offer to fans of Turn Based Grand Strategy games. In time, it would become known as one of, if not, the best Total War games ever made. You might ask yourself why out of all the newer Total War games is Rome the best? Well, there's several simple reasons.Pros:- Simple design, as it is one of the first TW games- Large, sprawling cities to battle in, but not too detailed so as to distract the player.- The single best Soundtrack you will find in any TW game.- Large map, but not on a ludacris scale such as Rome II.- Great choice of factions- Campaign and battle map look beautiful- This game can be played smoothly at its highest settings on any modern computer- Massive replay valueCons:- [post suggestions in the comment area]Overall:Rome is a nice and simple, beautifully crafted game. It is what CA was praised for in the Total War series. Rome II is way more technical with a great deal more to learn Honestly, the inlons about this game. Just as I have, almost all major and indie critics have given this game a 9/10, 95%, 4.5/5, etc. This was also given "14th Greatest Game of All Time" apparently and I do think it deserves it.10/10

number of helpful: 85 of 88 people (97%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												RTW has an epic feel.As of today, this game is nearly eleven years old.  So, the battle graphics are not as crisp as newer titles, the historicity of some units is sketchy (or just made up), and it seems that multiplayer is not smooth in Steam.  Fortunately, none of these mean a thing to me.  The heart of the game is in the grand strategy and the personal narrative.With over a hundred regions in which to play, the strategic game is where RTW shines. You need to plan where you will expand and where you will defend... and then be ready to adapt when the AI does not do what you expect. You may be the pawn of the Senate and serve at their beck and call.  You might try to expand against the weak.  You can follow the trade routes to gain riches through conquest.  You will find yourself occupying regions merely to stymie your enemies (and your allies). Or you might work your way towards all seven Wonders to reap their benefits.The twenty factions all fall into one of the major religio/cultural groupings. Some conquered peoples will not like your religion, but a few might. Some conquered peoples will happily accept you as overlord because you share the same cultural values... and the Spanish clans just don't like anyone. Some factions have great infantry, some have cavalry, and some do many things well.  Yet, you can usually find mercenaries (disgruntled locals, rival tribes, or thugs) who might fill the holes in your army.Yes, most negative reviews harp on about the lag in multiplayer and the poor graphics in battles.  If you need gratuitous violence or managing pixels in a free for all, then watch Mad Max: Fury Road or play League of Legends. If you want to make decisions that will impact your dominion fifty turns down the road, then this game can give it to you.  What kind of temples will you build in each region... or should you let the people keep their native religion?  Will a town become a recruiting station or a cash cow?  When you conquer a region, you'll have to decide to either just incorporate it into your lands as is, relocating half the people by enslaving them, or just slaughtering most of the inhabitants and stealing their goods.... and you'll find yourself using each throughout the campaign, because one size does not fit all.And guess what?  I don't fight the battles.  If I did, I'd never finish a campaign.  I hit the auto calculation button every time.  Why?  Well... there are a number of positions which you will fulfill in a game.  Benevolent multi-generational spirit guiding your family, governor of a province, Commander in Chief, general of an army, and captain of a unit. Playing all of these breaks the narrative for me... I play the macro game, i.e. the big picture.  I plot and scheme, I build cities, and recruit armies.  Then I send them out into the field.  How they do is up to them.  If they win... great! I must be a genius.  If they lose... nuts. Back to the drawing board.Two friends of mine, let's call them Doc and Bro, played RTW like this... Doc played the campaign map, i.e. he decided what units were built and where the battles were fought, but Bro fought all the battles.  Doc was the CinC and Bro was the General.  They played two campaigns in three years, but they remember both as epic stories of their teamwork.In addition to the war... campaign strategy, building armies, transportation of armies, theatres of conflict, fog of war, etc... you'll have to deal with natural disasters, (In one game, a young woman of my family married a promising young fellow, but he died a year later in an earthquake.), piracy, rebellions, brigands, bribery attempts upon your armies, old age, death in battle, adoptions, plagues (stupid unwashed barbarians), and assassination. (In one game, the youngest son of my German leader was sent to subdue Gaul and Hispania. This gave him a command of 10.  I marched him and his elite German veterans across the Alps to conquer Rome... but the Romans assassinated him.  With my hordes leaderless, the Romans proceeded to sieze Gaul and invade Germania.) All of these additional factors help create a unique narrative for each game.Oh, and when you play as a Roman faction, you'll need to keep an eye upon the Senate... how they view you, how the plebs (the masses) view you, Senatorial missions, and the official Senatorial stance with every other faction. For instance, you may have a great trade agreement with the Egyptians and a low standing with the Senate, but the Sentate demands that you attack Egypt... attacking Egypt will hurt your income considerably, but offending the Senate may cause them to label you as a rebel... what will you do?Certain events always happen... Aetna erupts and the plague breaks out in Macedonia, but certain other events happen only when certain triggers occur (the Marian reforms), while others, such as floods, are random.  But the big event for Roman players is the Civil War.  At some point the plebs will want you to deal with the Senate and/or at some point the Senate will either have enough of you or become paranoid of your growing power that they'll demand the head of your family to commit suicide.  If you agree, they'll do it every turn until your family ceases to exist.  If you're not ready for war, then you can comply with the Senate for a few years (and prune your family tree of bad apples in the process), but at some point you'll have to stand up to the Senate... at which point you go to war with all other Romans.  Talk about raising your anxiety.... sheesh!All of your characters really flesh out the narrative... the story of your family.  Spies, diplomats, assassins, admirals, generals, and governors all have character traits that make them who they are.  Some will be drunkards, perverts, and ne'er do wells, while some will be loyal, moral, and cunning.  They'll also tend to generate a following of hangers on, freeloaders, men of honor, mistresses, etc...  For instance, a son might come of age in your family with a command of 3... a natural born general... but on his way to the frontier to defeat the Dacians, his inner circle grows to include a Drunken Uncle and an Actor and they decrease his command ability by 3... Ouch!  He's now a zero...In the first two Total War games, Shogun and Medieval, you had family members, but not nearly as many as Rome.  So to help you manage them (and for the sheer fun of telling a story), RTW includes a family tree.The game's not perfect.  The legendary/semi-mythological units can be frustrating and the Egyptians were certainly not using chariots in the second century BC. Naval combat results can make you scratch your head.  Negative income numbers on the campaign map are definitely misleading. There is always the point at which you know you've won even though you may only be forty to seventy percent of the way to the finish... but that's true of a lot of games.There may be other games out there that have made improvements to the grand strategy game, but I've always found this one to be fun to return to.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I am the House of Julii.I am to the North of Italy. I am part of the Glorious Roman Republic, sharing with three other factions; the blue Scorpios (I think) who have decided to take a couple of islands and then the big parts of Africa. The green Brutii, who decided that looking ridiculous would best show the Greeks what's what. And I, wearing fantastically imperial red, who was tasked with sorting out the dirty Gauls.I quickly began a conquest that would put the Black Templars to shame, sending out army after army, conquering town after town. They tried to resist, but my men were worth two of theirs, and my men outnumbered their three to one. As we came, we took most of them slaves, built up my core towns, built as many temples to convince more people to shag as possible, and continued on our merry murdering way.Occasionally, the Guals or Brittony or Germans would manage to scrape together an entire army of 2000 people. These were the battles I, and my family, were born for. We smashed together, blood and sword and sinew, as my Velites threw their spears overhead, and cavalry quickly hit them from behind. Few enemies died facing us in the north, many ran and most died with sword wounds in their backs rather than face us.We tried peace once, and we paid the price with roman lives. When they begged for our mercy, they found only our gladius. We heard the lamentations of their women as they were taken back to mighty Arretium, our capital city. And how it had grown; on the back of slaves and the glory of our men, we raised great arenas and temples to show our glory! We raised great barracks to train our men! We grew the greatest of men to enforce our will! And the north of Europe was stained red with blood; the map of Europe was stained red with our flags.We found that land ran out quickly; Europa gave way before our bloodlust did, and we turned to look back. We were disgusted with what we saw. Corruption. Weakness. Our supposed equals made peace with the savages, our supposed superiors hide behind the walls of Rome. They whispered of treachery, but we knew weakness and corruption when we saw it. The spineless Scorpios had no trouble gaining the favour of the Senate; spending more time on their knees in glorious Rome than sword in hand over Carthage. The Brutii failed to live up to their brutish name; content with a paltry pile of sand, growing fat and lazy as we had grown lean and numerous in both flesh and glory.We recalled our armies to home, to the swell of the crowds. They chanted our name, and spat at the mentions of the Senate. All had been united under our banner; did not the Celts and Gauls and Germans and Thrycians alike not bend the knee to the glorious Romans, all beneath the bloody red banner of the Julii? Mars had made his favour clear; he doesn't favour cowards, and Jupiter didn't let the weak rule. We built temples in His Name, and spread his name further than even the diplomats know. All that was left was to follow the glory given to us, under the gaze of the gods and cheers of the people, we marched the final path.All roads lead to Rome.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Rome: Total War is a strategy game from Creative Assembly and published by SEGA. Rome: Total War is set during the timeline of the Roman Republic to its transition into the Roman Empire.Rome: Total War gameplay can be overwhelming for newcomers but its not hard to master the gameplay. First you can only play as Rome, choose one of three Roman royal family. You start on the campaign map with some settlement where you can expand it, train troops, train a diplomat and build your empire. You can engage in diplomacy with other faction such as the Greeks, Egypt or Gaul, make alliances or declare war. When it comes to battle, you can choose to auto resolve the battle if you outnumber the enemy or engage the fight in the battlefield where you will command your troops. This is the best part where you command hundreds or thousands of Roman Legion and Auxiliaries support to fight the Greek Hoplites or the barbarian army and watch them kill each other. Each army can be commanded by a general which will improve the army morale and increase the auto resolve chance of winning. Each general has some skill bonuses that can improve army or improve settlement when they become the governor. As General takes part in battle, their skill bonuses will improve.Rome: Total War is quite addicting to play. When you're done playing with Rome, other faction can be unlocked and then you can play as them. Then you can instead fighting Rome and defeat the greatest empire ever exist in history. The graphics may be old, and some technical issues may occur on newer system, but the game is more than playable. I recommend this.Rating 8/10

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Well.....reviewing this game is hard. For it's time, it was without a doubt one of, if not the greatest, strategy games of all time. However, comparing it to newer Total Wars,(except for ROME II, that is something else entirely) it lacks in several things, notably historical accuracy, diplomacy, and managing your government. For one, in historical accuracy, there are multiple nations(like Gaul, Spain, Greece, etc.) that are unified nations even though in real life they were a divided people, with seperate clans, city states, etc. but for some reason CA mashed a lot of city states and tribes together to form unified nations, which is complete bogus. Also, in historical accuracy, Egypt is not Hellenistic at ALL. They still have traditional Egyptian Paganism as their religion, and their units are traditional Egypitan ones, even though Egypt was now practically a Middle Eastern copy of Greece thanks to Alexander the Great. In diplomacy, there are very few options(some examples are trade rights, allaince,  map info, etc.) and, therefore, made diplomacy lose it's immersion. Finnaly, there is governemnt. For Roman factions, the Republic government is fairly adequately displayed, but in general, there really is no "government system" like in Empire Total War, although there is a family tree where you can set the faction heir, adding a bit of spice to government. If we put those those things aside, you will find a true classic of a strategy game-and I'm pretty sure most people here would agree with me. In a time where graphics made people look like horrible mutants, AI was as smart as your neighborhood stray dog, and strategy games lacked a lot of actual strategy, this game was revolutionary. The graphics, although considered inferior to today's games, probably looked really great to a lot of players back in 2004.  The jump from the previous Total War, Medieval, to Rome's graphics was absoultely stunning. The AI (which, to be honest, is not very much smarter than the neighborhood stray)  is competent despite occasional errors. Diplomacy, while lacking in true immersion, added a new level of strategy to games, as a system with more than just basic alliance/trade/war was pretty much only used in previous Total Wars and a few other grand strategy games, and even then it was really basic. And government, while being very basic, also adds to the strategy of the game, as you scramble to find a sutiable heir for your glorious (or, more often than not, not-so-glorious) empire. Speaking of empires, there are 20 factions, with about half of them playable, half not playable. Technically, there is a 21st faction, the Rebels. The rebels not only represent actual rebels, which I am perfectley ok with, but they also represent "minor factions" that CA left out of the game, which is kinda sloppy to me. However, all-in-all, the campaign is sound, if perhaps a tad disappointing to modern gamers. Now..on to battles. It is not possible to manage a nation without going to war, and this game certainly does not oppose that fact. You will end up in countless battles, usually with random weaklings who think they are better than you, but you will often find yourself matched against a worthy foe. If it is a land battle, you can do one of three things-Fight the battle out on a battle map, have the computer auto resolve the battle, or retreat. For naval battles, you only have the auto resolve option. For the battle map, you and everyone involved-whheter or not they are on your side-will command various units that can be trained in cities if you have the proper buildings. You command these soldiers to victory-or defeat-against the enemy. I personally belive CA did a great job on the battle mechanic of the game.If you like Total War games, strategy games in general, video games in general, or if you like life, then buy this game. Even if you don't like life, still buy it. This is a true classic of a strategy game, and you would be a fool to pass on it if you are a fan of the genre.Overall, 9/10.Also, this game definitely deserves the "Test of Time" award. An absolute classic of the strategy genre.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2013
												I played this game an unhealthy number of hours before so I had to pick up an original copy just to write this review.One of the best strategy games and my favourite in the series. An absolute classic!This game is a mix between turn based strategy (on the world map) and real-time strategy (on the battle map)8/10 Macro mechanics - you can manage your cities, conquer, develop and train your armies10/10 Micro mechanics - the feelings of managing thousands of units on the battlefields adds both realism and grandeur to battles. Tactical decisions are what wins fights. Positioning and good decisions that are not necesarily split decisions make the clashes immensly fun. DON'T YOU DARE use auto-resolve. You'll miss out on a lot.7/10 Graphics, because it's dated. Newer versions of the Total War series like Medieval 2, Shogun and the new Rome coming out have better graphics if that's what you're looking at, altough you shouldn't pay attention to the graphics.Learning curve isn't steep at all. Modding scene has some goodies in store afaik. Never tried multiplayer but it has to be tons of fun.It's an AMAZING game. It's like a middle ground between games like Civilization and Age of Empires and everyone should at least try it.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												They say rome wasn't built in one day, but that certainly depends on how much you play this game, and with a game like this, you can easily get stuck in front of your computer for hours. I've heard some good and some bad things about the sequel to this game, Rome II, so i figured i might try and review this one instead.I realize there's alot of TBS games kinda similar to this out there, but by some miracle i found my way through all those rip-offs and half bad ones, and found my way to this. Anyways, let's get to itNow even though this game might not have the best graphics, it's a good quality game, the game runs very smooth on even the worst of computers, I experienced a surprisingly few number of glitches and flaws. Also this game variates a lot more than you’d think, the terrain and weather and basically all the nature, and even soldiers surrounding the battlefield has an effect on the battle itself, and it manages to create a somewhat realistic atmosphere.You start of by choosing between a rich number of factions to play as, and each faction has their own abilities, starting points, diplomatic and offensive advantages, and of course they all are different difficulties. Now when you start you can also choose different campaign lengths and modes, but the ultimate goal, is to conquer the world. Even after you’ve reached your goal, and have gotten the “You Beat The Game!” message, there’s a lot to do.Now the game doesn’t have many tracks to get you humming along, in fact it has a couple of tracks running in the background, and some music to set the mood for a fight, but that’s in the rough it, and that’s one of the things letting this game a bit down in my opinion.To sum up, this game has a great costumization ability, and is good for a replay, or even two (to all the rome fanatics xD) not the best graphics or music but all in all, I give this an 7/10

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												The Total War series has an element of elegance to it. Exploring the ways of historical battle as finely and closely as it does is rare, and only some years after its first installment (Shogun) did the videogame industry begin to shoot similar titles. After the legendary Medieval, not many people believed that, apart from a change of setting to a different historical moment, a considerable amount of different content would come up. Then Rome shouted: you're wrong. This game brings pretty much every element of real-time strategy and tactics to the table: city development, troop development and upgrade (besides restoration of battered troops), a ranking system for experienced details that smells pleasantly like Total War spirit, and a turn-based diplomatic conflict and tension only rivaled by the Civilization series, in my opinion.Rome does have its flaws, mainly related to in-battle bugs and primary AI, but its general brilliance is undeniable. Total War lovers meet RTS lovers in this game, as we witness the rise of Rome from the eyes of three powerful political strata of the Roman Empire (houses Brutii, Julii, and Scipii), besides several pagan tribes from central and eastern Europe - some of which you can control after the main campaign has been finished -, as well as northern Africa. A complete set of compelling diplomatic progress is also displayed in Rome (you can constantly set up family alliances, strengthening the power of military stations in cities you control through the maturing of new generals and governors), as well as completude of technological upgrades, and plurality of maps for different battle strategy tastes, from snowy forests of Northern Germany to Spanish plains to Eastern European rocky hills. Rome: Total War puts you right into the heat of pre-medieval belli, the moments of Roman rise and fall, the pressure from the outside and from the inside. Intrigues, military management, civil complexities, and territorial tension.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												Rome: Total War. One of my all-time favorite games. Taking place in the late Roman Republic, you assume control of one of three Roman families vying for power. Depending on which family you select, the Senate will usually direct you against one of three adversaries - the Greeks, the Gauls, or the Carthaginians. The beautiful thing about Total War, however, is you can simply ignore the Senators and go on a campaign of your own... Egyptians? Invade them! Is the Senate demanding you join in on the war against the Macedon, but you'd rather become allies? Go for it! Just make sure you keep a home guard, because Civil War is a constant threat!It has been almost ten years since Rome's release. It hasn't aged terribly bad - the AI is somewhat atrocious, the graphics are dated, but the game is still genuinely satisfying. At the price Rome goes for during Steam's seasonal sales, there's really no excuse NOT to give this game a try. If nothing else, it is a taste of nostalgia before these types of games became more like movies and less like free-for-all sandboxes!

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
Basic InformationTitle:  Rome Total WarDeveloper:  The Creative AssemblyPublisher:  SEGAGenre:  RTS/TBS hybridGeneral ImpressionRome Total War is one of my favorite video games. I've been playing it since it was launched, in 2004 and even after so many years, it's still very entertaining and challenging. Thanks to the Total War series, I became interested in history and geography, two subjects which shaped my formal years of education. The game's engine is easy to tweak and modify, having a plethora of mods online. The best one remains Europa Barbarorum, a mod which stretches RTW' engine to its very limits. Even if to some players, Rome Total War's graphics might seem outdated, it remains an echelon by which all 3D RTS/TBS hybrids, measure themselves. None are its equal.Strong Points+ Very high modding potential.+ Steam Trading Cards.Weak Points- All the units look like clones of each other.- No Achievements.Rating 10/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews and Cubbes.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												How to properly experience Rome Total War. Step one: Start a new game playing as the Romans, doesn't matter the family.Step two: Decide how fast you want to get going by using cheats or not, usually depends onthe mood I'm in.Step three: Create an unstoppable army, or two, or 20, depends how fast you want the world to tremble at your feet.Step four: Send forth your armies into the lands of the barbarians, take their cities and sack them, burn them down, kill them all.Step five: Once the barbarians have been eradicated completely from the map, head for Greece, the home of the intelects.Step six: Send your armies to enslave the Greek peoples, beat them off their high horses and kill them slowly and painfully.Step seven: Once Greece has been pacified sucsessfuly, wait till you have a plauge in one of your cities, you will soon see why.Step eight: once you do have a plauge in one of your cities, get unimprtant agents like diplomats there, keep them for a bit, them send them to the south, in places like Memphis, Alexandria, or Carthage, large cities.Step nine: watch as thousands die from your own little biological terrorist attack, take it in.Step ten: Send your armies to finish off Carthage, Egypt and Numidia, enslave their peoples too, and make sure to kil the pharoh.Congrats, Romam regit omnia, Imperitor.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												In my opinion, this is still the best Total War game to date.Rome's got good combat, decent unit roosters for different cultures, good siege mechanics & decent city "building/development". You can also build forts & watch towers on the strategic map.Rome was made before the switch to the new engine, which means that each individual unit actually fight on an individual level, trying to hit enemies & block incoming attacks, instead of the crazy 1v1 kill-animation system. This have a major effect on how battles turn out & how they're conducted. If you got more units of similar skill & situation, they tend to do a fair bit better, instead of it just being a battle of attrition. Projectiles are fairly strong, but as far as I can tell, don't home-in on targets & ready, large shields greatly negate their effectiveness.I should mention that the music is the best in this title by a land-slide, it's always fitting & it's always get's you in the right mood for the situation.The one thing you may miss in this if you're used to the later titles is the naval combat, it's automated in Rome. Also, the graphics are very dated. Camera controls are janky & visual feedback is poor compared to later titles.Compared to the other Total War titles, there's only 3 other games that even come close to being as good as this one: Shogun 2, Medieval 2 & Empire(after milions of patches). I haven't played enough Warhammer to tell how it hold's up yet, but it looks promising.OBS!You may get random crashes to desktop if you buy it through steam, unless you go to the main folder, select everything, put it in a new folder within the main folder & then check integrity of the game & let it re-download everything. The game should then not crash, probably, it worked for me (I use Windows 7).

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Let's start with a confession. When Rome Total War was released I didn't buy it, didn't play it. Turn based sounded boring, I wanted real-time because that was cool. So when did I first play it? After Rome 2 was announced, I wanted to play with the ancient world but release was still months away. Then the release was utter garbage. Thus I turned to Rome Total War.So lets start with the TL;DR part.Good: The feel of combat. It's not fast, a bit to slow but formations collide. Good: Size, this game is huge. Large amount of provinces as well as factions. Improvement over Shogun 2, stuck in Japan.Good: Atmosphere, Senate missions as Rome, three seperate factions. Lots of different other factions too.Good: Mods, mods, mods. There some excellent mods out there for this game.Bad: Graphics, the graphics sure aged. Then again it's an old 3D game, they rarely age well.Bad: AI, AI isn't the smartest. The game is easily gamed, then again newer Total War's still are.Bad: Egypt. Egypt was greek at the time, not pharaohs, well not styled like the rulers of old. Just graphics but I'll mention it anyway.Bad: Resolution, no real widescreen support and no 1080p at all. Highest I can get is 1600x1400.So should I still get it? Well it's different for sure. I got into it after I played Medieval 2, Empire, Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai. I could make the journey back and was pleasantly suprised. On the other hand my main gaming PC wasn't very available at the time and I played mostly on a laptop. So older games was something I was stuck with either way.Give it a shot if you like ancient history, a slower strategy game and long battles. If you like historical accuraccy give Europa Barborium a spin. From a pure gameplay perspective it has an overwhelming amount of units, recruitment, moving and battles take ages but it's sure authentic.This is a great game, it has aged but not to much. It's deep but not to deep and I'm sort of sad the path Total War games have been taken lately. Still we can go back to this and I recommend you do that.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Rome: Total War is a fine example of game that has aged well, even after almost 10 years of the launch, it's a solid game .Particularly, the Total War series is my favorite when it comes to strategy games, the mixture of TBS with RTS is genial and well applied, allied to the historical factor that their games presents and you have a good source of fun with them.Rome: TW was a title much acclaimed when it launched, for the reasons described above and for its innovation, It's an addictive game that manages to insert you in the campaign and leave you completely focused on the goal of conquer and recreate the legacy of the Roman Empire. The gameplay may seem complicated at first, But you can absorb as much of the campaign map and battles works by playing the tutorial. Throughout the game you can also enable the tips of AI that will enhance learning. The enemy AI is good, although sometimes it may seem very easy on the lower difficulties. The main focus of the game are the battles,  so the diplomatic  and political party is not as well addressed, nevertheless I did not miss this factor.The graphics are outdated but still perfectly playable, the sound quality is magnificent, as well as Hellenistic soundtrack, the speeches of generals before battle is a small detail but shows how much the developers have applied to the game, they are exciting! The Total War series has a solid fan base, it is possible to find many mods that improve, enhance and add replay value to the game. The expansion Barbarian Invasion is a good choice to play under another historical perpective.The downside is that are technical problems that an old game shows, especially in newer OS. I lost a save that was corrupted in a campaign well advanced, it was very sad. Once you learn to play well, the AI also seems to be limited in combat and especially in the campaign, making it easy to match. But certainly this game deserves attention of those who enjoy history and a good strategy game.8/10

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Note: I have played this game for embrassingly numerous hours outside Steam, certainly many thousands.The Total War series revolutionized a strategy genre that was stagnating. After years of the same things over and over again, strategy games with only campaigns and no war, sitting and waiting for this mechanic or that to play itself out, games that made the GUI a bit messier and called it depth, features that just made the same stuff a bit more Heath Robinson and called it progress and innovation, battles where you watched columns of numbers, or 7-8 little RTS guys bip and bop for 30 seconds until the game told you who won... Total War brought in a tactical scope with depth to it, actual battlefields where real time decision-making and some sensible tactical considerations played roles, and where the clash was a grand spectacle. In one fell swoop, this series revitalized the genre, indeed carved out its own genre - strategy games where real time wargaming is actually a thing.Then, some time into the series, this game - this beautiful, beautiful game came along. Not content with what they'd achieved already, they made a game so good it broke the mould. Not content with creating their own groundbreaking genre, they then pushed further.It might have aged now, and it isn't such a surprising, groundbreaking thing now as it was back then, and it has its warts and annoyances (like all of the games in the series) but I still have to say that for me, this is possibly the best computer game ever made. Certainly one of the best.Also, it is a great family game, as long as the subject matter is ok for your tribe, we have had many years of fun out of these games. It is not bloody and gratuitous at all, although obviously war is violent in itself.There is nothing else that does computer wargaming like the Total War series, and this is the glorious pinnacle of it. 100/10

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												WARNING FOR WINDOWS 10 USERS AND POSSIBLE OTHERS: The game got a post-Gamespy update that will cause the game to do all kinds of crazy display stuff and crash. What you need to do is turn off anti-aliasing by default by going into the game's installation folder, preferences folder, then preferences file and make sure AA_QUALITY says AA_QUALITY:AA_ OFF. This should let you launch the game. If you wish to turn on AA from there, you can do so in NVIDIA Control Panel or any other equivalent program, as turning it back on in the menus will cause it to crash again.IF YOU GET REALLY BAD FRAMERATES AND LAGGY INPUT NO MATTER YOUR SPECS: Right-click the game in your library, click properties, then click Set Launch Options. In the text box, type the three characters "-ne" without the quotes and press okay. This should fix that problem for most people out there.With that done, I'd like to say that although this game is a bit primitive compared to modern TW games, it still can be a very fun game.  Pros:-The Campaign map is very no frills compared to modern TW games. You can build any building in any city, public disorder is easy to maintain, and it just lacks feature bloat of later games. The game is all about the battles, something I'd wish would come back after games like Attila.- The battles can look and play better than modern TW games in some ways. Losing units will actually be beaten back and enveloped by superior forces, soldiers will respond to orders at different times, and the engagements can have some real clash and weight to them. -There's actually strategy to the strategy map. I wasn't a huge fan of M2/Empire/Napoleon/Attila's maps because they tended to have lots of wide open plains, while Rome 1+2 and Shogun 2 had lots of limiting terrain features where you could create chokepoints and use terrain like mountains and rivers to your advantage.Cons:-Battles can be over a little too quickly. I kind of get whiplash at how fast I go from marching, to melee, to routing an enemy army.-The flipside to things like independent unit movement is that response can be sluggish, sometimes often so bad that I can't tell if the game knows if I ordered them to do anything.-Pathfinding can be garbage sometimes, especially in cities.-You can still get cascade moments where your empire is powerful enough that you're just auto-resolving your way across large swaths of the map at some points.Overall, I was surprised by how much I enjoyed the game despite not playing it since roughly around its launch. Once you get over some usability issues, there's a game here that's aged better than it has any right to.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game is by far, my favorite game. Hands down, no competition. It is old, but I've yet to see any other strategy game come close to this. The graphics are decent, considering its age. The gameplay is complex enough to not be bored and just steamroll through everything, yet simple enough to actually know how to use every feature this game has to offer. The game is basically you controlling a faction during the time of the Roman Republic, and trying to become the best nation. Diplomacy is simple and allies will betray you constantly, unless you would just completely dominate them (and even then, they still might attack you!) The AI is pretty simple to defeat, their entire strategy seems to be just throwing all of their units at you and seeing who wins. The challenges come when you get into the Roman Civil War. This is an in-game event where the 4 roman factions fight each other for control of Rome. Up until this point, you've just been steamrolling through barbarians with your heavy legionnaires. Once the Civil War starts, you're fighting 3 other roman factions (2 of which have just as much land as you if not more, each) and they have the same troops as you. If you're not playing a roman faction then this will never happen, but it's called ROME total war for a reason. If you're into strategy games, buy this game. Even if you're not, you should at least give it a try. The controls might be difficult to use at first, but the tutorial is very helpful. You will probably lose your first few campaigns, but once you get the hang of the game it will be so much fun.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Rome: Total WarThe game that launch the Total War series towards heights that it could've never dreamed of. This game is a turn-based strategy game where you take command the various factions during the Roman Era as you command, build, govern and attack Rome's enemies.The battle system unlike the system you will see in the modern day versions of the game is really simplistic. Sort of like an almost modern update of Imperial Glory. Now of course, the usual complaint would be "OMG the game is too hard" or "OMG the online players are wrecking me" Luckily the game has an in-depth tutorial plus you have all the time in the world as this game offers various combat both historical and custom made as you polish your skills in battle. And also being a leader of Rome.The advisor system is really helpful as they give advice towards the player. DO NOT turn it off if your new. Keep that option for advisor input set to "High". Plus the User Interface for manging your territory and what not is simplistic as well.Now bewarn, save often. Some of the daily tasks that the senate assigns you don't really give you concrete directions. For some of them it's a simple click of the "zoom in towards target location" while others it's "Find this city" and your just like "Um okay...WHERE?!" some of these tasks are important as it may further your position in the Roman government.If you still want a simplistic Total War game this is for you.

												This is a perfect classic of the Total War series. In short, you have the following:1) a huge map.2) massive armies.3) unlimited options when it comes to planning out your campaign.There is so much more I could mention that makes this game great, but I'd hate to write an entire novel about it. Just know that it sets a nice atmosphere and it's a great strategy game.However, keep note of a few annoying things:-Path finding for units can be very lousy sometimes, and there are some glitches routing as well. If a unit is defending the walls in a siege battle and they panic and route, they don't actually route for real. They just stand around idle all the time until someone kills them all off. -The AI, no matter how much of an effort you make, can be incredibly stupid at times. This is a trait common in all of the Total War games, but it shouldn't be too awful except for siege battles.Otherwise, this game is definitely a classic of the TW series. The pros greatly outweigh the cons.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2011
												This is the number one game in my library. For over a year, it was the only game other than Spore and the contents of the Orange Box. Five years later, I still go back to it every now and then. I've had many a 14-hour marathon day playing Rome Total War, quite often back to back. I'm pretty sure I got a chance to play as every civilization before I switched computers and lost my progress. I've even gone through the Barbarian Invasion campaign a few times. Honestly, if I'd never bought Civ V, I'd have well over 1,000 hours racked up by now.This is strategy at its purest. Not only do you have the strategy of "How do I move around my armies and generals and funds to best maintain and expand my empire?" you also have the battles themselves. Many games do only one or the other, and those games can go hang. I'm not going to go into detail about the games mechanics and why they're good or bad; instead, I'm going to regale you with but a few of the ridiculous stories that have come out of my 800+ hours.*My British faction leader, supported by two other armies, slaughters a quarter of the entire Brutii force over ten years, littering Poland with heroic victories. He eventually meets his end, known as "the Legendary," defending a town against a Roman force three times his size. Succesfully.*An elite squad of Berserkers sacrifice themselves on the walls of Rome itself, eliminating two entire legionary cohorts and flanking the wall's other defenders.*Four hoplite units hold Sparta against a full-size Roman army, earning a 100:1 k:d ratio.*My prize Egyptian army meets a humiliating defeat at the hands of Ponitc troops, navigates around the army, and marches straight into a Pontic city.*A Roman town is betrayed by Spain's finest, throws them off every year for three years until reinforcements can come in and ravage Spain's western coast.*A Carthaginian gambit to take Rome early fails miserably; a generation later, we're back with five armies that now include line-ravaging Armored Elephants.*Betraying Rome by landing an army next to her city - as well as every other non-Brutii city on the peninsula, and bloackading every Roman port east of Palma.*Falling in love with my faction heir, as he's my only general who can fight at night. He later on earns three bonus command stars at night, and sacks Constantine by the light of the moon.It's a glorious game, one with an infinite supply of stories. Go make your own.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Rome: Total War is the Third game in the Total War series, released in 2004. Being 11-years old, as well as having several newer titles in the Total War series, Rome: Total War considerably shows it's age; However, with that being said it is still a fun, interesting game in the overall series. The game takes place prior to the middle ages, After the fall of the Roman Republic, during the Early Roman Empire. As is typical with the Total War series, You start off with a small number of player factions to choose, in this case 3, and unlock additional factions as playable once you conquer them.Also as is typical of a Total War game, gameplay is divided between the real-time battles when in combat, and the turn-based actions of exploration, nation-building, and diplomacy. Rome: Total War has been consistently rated as one of the highest games throughout the Total War Series, based on IGN, Metacritic, and GameRankings, and has a large following, as well as many player-made mods. Despite it's age, Rome: Total War is a strategy game any fan of the Total War series should have.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												A pretty decent game which turns out to be great with Europa Barbarorum modification. While the vanilla game is okay, it gets pretty boring after a while, because it's just very easy even on the highest difficulty and you just cakewalk everything. Moreover, multiplayer is terrible, because the game is unbalanced and community is terrible. Everybody just gets archers and camps in one place until other players get bored and try to attack but they are then in a losing position. AI is dumb, it plays terribly on campaign map, attacking with only a few units an entire army, leaving cities defenseless and in battle mode they just rush at you blindly, except horse archers who only harass you and run away and you have to chase them across entire map, which is extremely frustrating as it takes a long time.However, even with its shortcomings, it's a good game, and it can be much better with modifications, especially with a great Europa Barbarorum mod that makes the game way more interesting. Is it worth getting today? Or should you just play other Total War game?It is definitely worth getting for Europa Barbarorum, just like Medieval II is worth getting just for Broken Crescent mod. Otherwise... not so much, as the vanilla campaign is much better in ie. Shogun Total War, and the AI tends to be much less frustratingly annoying and dumb there too.

content:
Posted: February 26
Rome: Total War is pretty cool, I guess. Back in the year 2000, a time when every music group went out of their way to look goofy, a little development studio named Creative Assembly decided to release a strategy game called "Shogun: Total War." The game mixed grand strategy and real time elements to create what was essentially a perfect formula of kingdom management and army control. The game was pretty successful, and two years later they released "Medieval: Total War" in 2002.  The game stepped away from the era of Feudal Japan and instead focused on Medieval Europe, hence the name. This game was also a success, and finally, two years later, Creative Assembly released what I personally believe to be their Magnum Opus. Rome: Total War was released in 2004, and that rhymes.Set during a period when killing someone was a lot more difficult because you had to get in pleasant conversation distance of one another. Rome: Total War's campaign begins during the early days of the Roman Republic. Or "early", I guess. You play as a various number of factions, some being unlockable as you conquer them in game, each one has a unique quality to it that comes into play during the battles. Now, I'm going to admit, I spent way too much time playing this game, and I'm probably just going to gush on it. "But Dirk you World Champion Hugger." You start. "Steam says you only have 15 hours of total play time."Well first, shut up, and second: Rome was one of the first PC games I actually bought myself after a long and backbreaking career in pig wrestling. I'm pretty sure I have almost, if not more than 1000 hours all together in this game. Though in those 1000 hours I haven't even played the Alexander expansion, but I heard that's good too. Campaign mode is broken into two segments, the campaign map where you control your entire empire, and the battle map where you command an army in combat. In the campaign map you build cities, train armies, make diplomatic agreements with other factions, and call Carthage stinky idiots for not releasing their hold on Sicily this instant. When diplomacy does break down, then it's time to get a little violent. Invading enemy territory involves you moving your armies around the campaign map like board game pieces, and having them attack enemy cities or armies. When the battle begins you zoom in to get a command eye view of the battle where you command each unit like a normal strategy game.Something that Rome and a few other games had that newer games do not is a captain system where, if you don't have a general in an army, it would instead be commanded by a captain within the army. If the Captain can prove himelf in a climatic battle or over the course of a war, then there's a chance that that captain can be promoted to General and actually become a named character.Generals themselves are fairly unique as well, each of them is named and can be improved or sabotaged independently. With every victory, the general can become a better commander and earn some traits, these traits can be positive or negative. For instant, a general may grow disgusted by war and have no taste for bloodshed, giving his army a morale penality. Or maybe he'll become better at army management and be able to move further each turn. Or maybe he'll just go crazy and talk about how his army will win because they have cooler hats. This and added into a pre-battle speech system where your general's speech can change depending on traits, gives the game a very neat little roleplaying element that helps give a narrative to your campaign. When your lords pass away they leave a history that will stick until the end of your campaign.Commanding your armies in battle is a very easy affair. You can control on unit, or multiple units at once, prepare their formation before the battle, and listen your the general's speech before it all goes down. For 2004, this part of the game was groundbreaking, since it was uncommon to see so many 3D rendered units on screen at once. It still holds up, especially if you put the unit scale to max. But should you play Rome: Total War?Yeah, probably, at least if you're a Total War fan who somehow hasn't played the classics. It's considered one of the best games ever made by people who aren't as great as me, and I would consider it at least in my top 10, if not my top 5. There are some problems, enemy campaign AI get sometimes wig out, having things happen like nations ask for an alliance one turn and then declare war the very next, but there are mods that help fix this to an extent. The modding scene is pretty great as well, with Europa Barbarorum and Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ coming to mind. I would give R:TW my golden seal of approval and say you should pick it up some way. It usually gets really cheap during sales as well. Rome: Total War gets 5 overly dramatic speeches out of 5. Bananas are curved because they grow towards the sun.The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curationOh man, this review wasn't all that funny, was it?

number of helpful: 15 of 20 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Rome: Total War was the third Total War game from Creative Assembly, and it was the best one at the time. As it was expected, it was a game of epic-scale real-time battles and impressive attention to historical realism and detail. Shogun was a promising start for the series, while Medieval built on that promise to create an even more engrossing strategy game. Rome took the next step, and it was as much a revolutionary step as it was an evolutionary one, thanks to the at the time new 3D graphics engine that made the series' tactical battles (featuring thousands of soldiers) better than ever. The results were nothing short of spectacular, helping make Rome: Total War the very definition of an epic strategy game and a beloved classic of the gaming industry.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												They may try, but they will never beat Rome: Total War.Of course, the game is ageing, and with each new Total War iteration struggling to refine the gameplay it was always going to age somewhat badly. The soldiers which at the time seemed technological marvels now look blocky and cartoony, the campaign map looks less vibrant and more modular, the little portraits, banners and such all look unimpressive and much of the interface seems vaguely unresponsibe, low resolution and unattractive.But they will never beat this game.What was Rome Total War? Think of cars coming into a world of carts, think of chocolate coming into a world of porridge. People had dreamed of seeing the vast armies portrayed as 2D sprites in the original Shogun: Total War in glorious full 3D, and this game delivered in every way imaginable. The roman cities were sparkling, shining in the sun, the landscapes were the scale of the real world and the armies were, indeed, massive. The formations looked just as good as you always hoped they would, and things like charges had the very, excellent, feeling that we had all imagined.Not only that, but the game was deep and huge, with hours upon hours of varied gameplay promised, with any faction we wiped out in one playthrough being available to control in the next campaign - something that Empire: Total War really should have allowed. The (strangely Australian) tutorial woman left nothing to chance, and we never felt out of control, rushed, or under any pressure that was not a direct result of our own actions (all faults that would plague later titles in the series, in my eyes)The characters were great - real world names popping up here and there, generals increasing in effectivness. Money flowed relatively easily if you were but a little thoughtful about it, and developing more advanced troops was intuitive and straightforward.In short, this game got everything right. It has just the right mix of gameplay imposition and gamer imposition, input from both sources comign together to create a sandbox empire building experience that could suck you in and satisfied you for tens, hundreds of hours.Amazing game.

												Hello, Lets get straight to the point, Rome: Total War is a RTS game, Althought when you look at it you say, "I think this is what my grandpa played." you are Wrong! RTW is one of the best strategy games out there, don't let its age and graphics trick you that this is a bad game. If you are new to Total War games this is a game to get you started. RTW take reletively low disk space (2-3 GB) and is amazing at almost every aspact it has. True you might say how is this different from Total War Rome II. This game is easy and you get a good idea on what TW games are based on. This is one of the oldest RTW's but I would call it one of the best. From units to strategies, this game is amazing at simulating a battle, physics are amazing and anything you do changes the world around you. So if you want to play as a roman and expand the wast territories of the SPQR, Become the supreme ruler of the Roman Empire or destroy the romans and erase them from history. This is a game for you.Overall I would say I give this game 8/10 for being absolutely amazing. I really want to give it 9/10 but since it is old and Rome II or TW Attila is more modern, lets stick to 8/10Hope this review was helpful, enjoy the game and take care!

Posted: May 3, 2015
												A classic. One of the best pc games of all time.If you've ever dreamed of being an ancient general like Caesar or Hannibal, or conquering the ancient world as the romans did, this is the game for you !The game's main campaign is set during the rule of the late Roman Republic and early Roman Empire with the player assuming control of one of three leading Roman families. Other factions are playable once they have been unlocked. Gameplay consists of real-time tactical battles framed within a turn-based strategic campaign.  On the large strategic scale, players spend each turn managing diplomacy, developing infrastructure, moving armies, and managing the population's growth and public order. On the smaller scale, real-time battles against enemy armies take place with the player commanding forces that can contain thousands of individual soldiers.The game is also featured in tv series about ancient battles - Decisive Battles and Time CommandersSome other roman themed games : Caesar 3, Qvadriga, Grand Ages: Rome,  Europa Universalis: Rome..

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												As the user-defined tags suggest this is a historical strategy game.  The overworld campaign is a turn-based grand strategy- sort of a simplified Civilization.  The battles are mostly real time, with a toggle for 2x or 3x, so I guess it could be argued there is a 4x element to the battle.The campaign takes a long time to finish, but it is good training if you want to play multiplayer.  There are some troops that don't seem to be very good relative to their costs-  I'm thinking the Arcanii (why only 16????????!!!!!!!!!!), but for the most part the game seems pretty balanced.The biggest downside for me was the fact that this game crashes every 4th or 5th battle, and I hear I am not the only person who has this problem.  The public order system can also be wonky- I lost a settlement to a gladiator revolt, then recaptured it and two turns later there was another gladiator revolt with the exact same amount of gladiators. Overall, I would strongly reccomend this game if you like the idea of massive battles, tactical thinking, or time consuming strategic considerations.  I know I loved it.

number of helpful: 28 of 48 people (58%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19
												This is one of my favorite games, and, despite what my steam playtime may suggest, I have spent hundreds of hours playing the CD version. I cannot recommend the game highly enough.  The vanilla gameplay is excellent, and there is a wide range of mods that adds tremendously to that - Rome: Total Realism, Europa Barbarorum and others. So why the thumbs down? Because the steam version of this game is essentially unplayable on modern computers. My brand new desktop, which plays Total War: Warhammer on high settings at 60 fps, cannot manage large battles in this 13-year-old game at higher than ~30-35 fps. I've tried just about every fix for this that can be found online, from copying DX9 dlls to running in XP SP2 compatibility mode to running the game in borderless windowed mode at my full screen resolution. I've even turned all the settings down to low, and the problem still persists. The upshot is that this game is simply drastically unoptimized for modern hardware and operating systems. I'm at the point where I'm considering installing windows XP on a separate partition just to see if that will do any good, but I'm not holding out much hope. I understand that not everyone has this problem, but I've experienced it thus far on three modern computers, running windows 7 and windows 10. Anyone considering purchasing this should be aware of this problem.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
												Rome Total War was in many ways the best that the Total War series had to offer, it was the game that took a giant leap forward and set the standard that it's own developers have yet to break. Despite game breaking bugs and broken promises about modding support Rome Total War still manages to give you a grand experience as you grow your empire towards total domination.   For those who have never played a Total War game it has two distinct elements to it, the first is the campaign map, this is an overview map where you build your cities, train units, send diplomats and assassins to your enemies and friends and move your armies around in a turn based grand strategy style and while it has nowhere near the dept of a true grand strategy game it does the job well enough that you forgive it, especially once you start to touch upon the second, and the most important, major aspect of a Total War game, the battles.   When two armies meet on the campaign map you are taken out of the turn based strategy and thrown right smack in the middle of a real time strategy battle with hundreds or perhaps even thousands of soldiers ready to fight and die. You move your soldiers around in squads of archers, swordsmen, cavalry, etc. Each faction has a semi-unique list of units they can employ, from the various types of Roman Legionaries to the Carthaginian War Elephants to the hilariously historically inaccurate flaming pigs. Each unit has it's own skills and abilities and while there is some level of rock -> paper -> scissors involved, the majority comes down to tactics, sure Spearmen beats cavalry, unless the cavalry happens to be charging them from behind.The game is pretty too, with a good amount of detail considering the scope of the battles, the soundtrack fits almost perfectly with the mood of the game and sounds of battle are utterly satisfying. Even the load screen are great, each one featuring a different quote from a period persona although a lot of mistakes were made by whoever typed in those quotes.It is not all roses however, Rome has a number of problems too the first and foremost of which being the same one that continues to plague Total War games to this day. The AI is completely and utterly inept. Whether it is trying to assemble an army by sending individual units walking through your territory one by one, letting you eliminate them piecemeal or displaying it's rather uncanny ability to form a perfect battle line and then break it in half just before engagement letting you flank the enemy at will you can't help but feel that this is somehow below the standards of the rest of the game and in fact modders have proven that making the AI not suicide every battle is indeed possible.In addition to that rather large issue there is a number of smaller ones, the campaign map is incredibly shallow and while the movement style is a big leap up from Medieval it still feels very arcadey. The squalor bug, or feature, as the developers would call it, whereby all cities automatically revolt if they grow to a certain population size. The lack of full scale modding, although Rome features a bunch of great mods there are certain things you are simply not allowed to do, such as adding more factions to the game. And despite the developers saying it's possible and banning people from their forums who says otherwise, it really isn't possible.Also the game throws any sense of historical accuracy out the window, from the equipment to the map to the very factions very few things in the game represent the time period accurately, this is something that will bother some people while others will ignore it. For me it only becomes annoying when people take their knowledge from Rome and try to apply it elsewhere.All in all, Rome Total War is a great game, it set the standard for all Total War Games to come and despite a number of annoying bugs and problems it still remains a great game to this day.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Totally addictive.  A great game. If you are looking for something to fill up quite a bit of time for quite a small amount of money this is it.   It took me forty hours or so to get through one campaign, that is win one game.  After finishing a campaign successfully you can pick any of the nations on the map to use.As for the gameplay yourself you start off with some citystates.  You must develop your cities in order to increase monitary capital, defenses, religion, law and order, sanitation etc. all the while keeping the citizens at a content state.  They can and will revolt and kick you out if they get to dissatified.  You also must recruit a variety of soldiers to defend your cities and conquer other cities and generals.  You build siege weapons, ladders, siege towers, battering rams, or later when you get them elephants to scale or break down walls to take other fortresses and eventually rule the world!As you can tell there is a bit of a learning curve with  this game.  Save often at first.  With a little bit of patience you can learn to do all I have mentioned and more.  This sort of game is not for everyone, however, it is hard to know if you are really going to like it unless you give it a sincere try.  The game is a bit dated and can be hard to load at times.  Once loaded I have noticed no bugs.  It is a good game if you have a computer that is not 100% up to date as it will work on older computers that might not have the specs for the newer Total War Games.  So far I have played Total War Rome, Shogun 2, and Medieval.  They are all enjoyable in  their own ways.  So for those asking which game is the best I would recommend getting the one for the area of history you are most interested in as long as it will work on your computer.  If you like it you will most likely enjoy the others as well.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Rome Total War is inarguably the best in the Total War series, with Medieval 2 coming in a close second. This game is a must have for all RTS and Grand Strategy fans! This game is perfect for a newcomer to the total war series, it's simple and easy to get into but tremendous fun to play.  Don't be discouraged thinking that old games are stupidly hard, with cluttered UI and bad graphics, it's not the case here!The city management and diplomacy is interesting. The UI is polished and easily understandable.  There's a great unit variety and especially the Roman legions are really interesting. There's nothing like mowing down hordes of barbaric tribes with your Legions. Sure the graphics are outdated but it still looks decent, at least you can crank them up to the max even on an old laptop. Total War Rome looked WAY better in it's age (2004) than how Rome II looks compared to today's standards. There are a huge number of mods, and complete overhauls out there to further enhance the gameplay and graphics. When you buy the game you also get the Barbarian Invasion DLC included which places the whole game to a completely different aspect. There's also another expansion called Total War Rome Alexander but it's perhaps the most forgettable one in the franchise.This game is in my personal top 10 of all time, worth every penny if you like strategy games go buy it and I guarantee you won't regret it! I played hundreds of hours of it (I owned a physical copy).

content:
Posted: April 4
												I love Rome: Total War. It was one of the first strategy games I played. I sunk hours into this game, playing it long in to the night. Just one more turn... just one more battle... It's highly addictive and great fun.So why do I NOT recommend this game? Because the Steam version seems to have a serious problem with modern systems.I originally had the Gold collectors disc (that includes the base game plus the Barbarian Invasion and Alexander expansions). It ran fine on an older Core 2 Duo laptop with integrated graphics on medium settings. However, I'm currently trying to run the Steam version on an HP Pavillion laptop that has an i5-6200U CPU and NVIDIA GeForce 940M graphics card. If I max-out the settings it runs at about 8 to 10 fps. If I turn everything down low I can coax out 25 fps.From the forums it seems I'm not alone in this predicament. A number of "fixes" have been suggested but none of them have worked for me. Apparently the disc version works OK but I stupidly gave it away.I will undoubtedly continue trying to resolve this issue and if I do then I'll gladly update my opinion but for now I simply cannot recommend anyone buy this game, even though I love it so much.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Rome: Total War is the oldest Total War game available on Steam, and can be considered the basis of the rest of the games which followed (although I would totally rebuy Medieval: Total War if they ever added that). In previous games, the overlying board played like a giant Risk board, where you moved armied from province to province, instead of having the entire campaign map laid out and moving your armies to specific locations. This was a DRAMATIC shift for the series, and one which really helped to establish it at something unique from other strategy games.Like all Total War games that followed, you move your armies around the map to strategic locations in your turn, then the rest of the other players' turns elapse. At any point where two armies meet and fight, the option to autoresolve or fight on a tactical campaign map is provided, which is where the real-time portion of the game takes place.Rome is also the first game in the series where the armies were polygonal as opposed to sprites, which was a RIDICULOUS feat for graphics at the time. It's still relatively streamlined compared to modern Total War games, but it still stands up to this day. It's an excellent, excellent game, and well worth playing even now, a decade after its release. While I don't personally hold it up as the best example of the series, I know many people who do and I cannot fault their opinions - this is a damn fine game.

Posted: July 3, 2011
												Looking for the best RTS game money can buy? then look no further. Rome: Total War is by far one of the greatest games in Total War history with the best balanced gameplay in any Total War game.You run an empire of choice, first you must unlock other factions as this game is focused on Rome so you are only able to choose from them at first. Beat the main game and you unlock a smattering of factions. Then you can also hack the game files and unlock every other non-playable factions and of course play as them. Great fun.This game is many years old but the graphics stand the test of time, still pleasing to the eye as well as the first fully 3D Total War game.The game can range from been easy, to a total nightmare of course that also depends on the players skills. Something negative is really, the Rome factions on the higher diffculties are amazingly tough, but they are also overpowerd to play as. Overall amazing game easily a 9.8/10 :) - Dean

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
												Rome: Total War is an incredible game. I remember buying it discounted at EB Games and thinking 'I can play this for a couple of hours'. Oh, how wrong I was. I played over 150 hours in less than a year (not really an acheivement, granted) and enjoyed every moment of it. Oh, how satisfying it is plundering through Gaul with highly trained Roman legions and crushing successor states under your hoplite phalanx. The game really put things into perspective for me. It showed me how the centuries-old Greek phalanx was finally swept aside by the Roman legions. Mind you, I was overpowered by them when I first tackled them as the Romans. My only proper disappointment is that Rome is overpowered (to be fair, it was at the time but not as much), Hellenistic pikes are underpowered and Egypt is anachronistic and overpowered.All aside, I've spent much time playing this and have loved it. Nothing is more fun than tearing chariots to shreds with Spartan spears.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Close your eyes. Breath in the moist grass. The sweat of soldiers, armed to the neck with shields, swords, spears, and bows. Now, feel the ground beneath you shake, the war cries of the Gauls sending shivers down your body. The onagers and repeating ballista creaking along the grassy pasture. The synchronized march of the Roman army coming to meet the opposition. You open one eye, admiring the shiny--CLOSE YOUR EYES I SAID. Now, ahem, raise your arms into the sky, feeling the breeze and the tension of a battle wafting through your hands. Close your fist around that air and hover lightly into the air, looking down at the approaching armies. You're actually a quadrocopter, so you can float.Seriously, however, this game is amazingly fun. The campaign is captivating and the custom battles are entertaining. The possibilities are endless. There are so many factions and armies to make! Strategies to plan. Armies to deploy. Units to command. Towns to conquer. Upgrades to be made.I recommend this game to strategy game lovers!

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Though aged now, the original R:TW was a fun and genre-establishing product of its' time. What I haven't done 'til recent times was try any mods for it.  If you're a true fan of ancient history/ancient warfare, I would highly suggest the Europa Barbarorum (1.2) mod, which adds incredibly depth of historical accuracy, and a myriad of changes to the way the game works and unit/texture differences. It builds upon the old structure and enhances it to the extent that the vanilla/original game appears cartoonish and amateurish in comparison. For anyone who has wondered time and again why for instance our ancient Romans seem to be popularly portrayed extensively in a modern UK english accent, (for some bizarre reason), you'll be happy to hear true latin, ancient greek and celtic languages. Units are also elaborately detailed, and given large, informative descriptions. It's part history-lesson, part classic R:TW experience.It is also an extremely entertaining challenge to seasoned veterans of the TW series like myself.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Not only a classic of the genre, but also the best of the total war series imo. This game beats every other title out there in terms of a combined turn-based/rts historical game (especially with mods, which virtually increases the game length by hundreds--possibly thousands--of hours. Graphics: They're okay for its time (about a 6-7/10), but it may feel outdated for some newer gamers. Try some mods, and it'll feel more new. With that being said, about 7/10 with the mods in mind.Gameplay: Very smooth, responsive battle animations. If you can control your cavalry well, you can handle any opponent with proper flanking and timed troop engagement. The turn-based aspect may seem somewhat outdated, but there are mods that will bring the diplomacy among other parts of the game to unrivaled levels. 10/10I'm not going to comment on anything else, since I think this game is all gameplay with some visuals to create immersion. There is a grand and truly epic feel to the campaign, so anyone with some interest in history would enjoy it.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I was looking for new strategy games, and I didn't find any that would match the simple, straight forward, but always replay-worthy quality of Rome:TW.Of course, it is outdated now. Of course Rome II for instance has much nicer graphics. Of course, Rome:TW has its flaws.What the newer games all lack is the concentrated energy of this old style game. They give you bling bling, but then they limit your playing experience because the devs want to shape the way you play a game, instead of presenting the player with opportunities.I'll give you a - limited - example, just to show the main point, I could go into detail in many respects, but here's one that should show what I mean in principle. In Rome:TW, you could march an army without a general into hostile territory. Or you could scale walls with a single infantry unit - it's your choice (and your troops' funeral, perhaps). In Rome II, you are forced to recruit a general. You must replenish resources, even if you would like to get an advantage by sacrificing some units. You cannot win a game based on skill and creative tactics, but only by playing by the book. But the game will throw an achievement your way in exchange for freedom...I miss old style games like some old software, that did exactly what it was supposed to do and nothing else.Time to besiege Alexandria, brb
