content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												Rome: Total War is the third Total War game from England's Creative Assembly, and, to make a long story short, it's the best one yet. It was naturally expected to build on its illustrious predecessors, which featured epic-scale real-time battles and impressive attention to historical realism and detail. Shogun: Total War was a promising start for the series, while Medieval: Total War built on that promise to create an even more engrossing strategy game. With Rome: Total War, Creative Assembly takes the next step, and it's as much a revolutionary step as it is an evolutionary one, thanks to a beautiful new 3D graphics engine that makes the series' tactical battles--featuring thousands of soldiers--better than ever. The results are nothing short of spectacular, helping make Rome: Total War the very definition of an epic strategy game.Where do you want to go today? The ancient world beckons, if you're brave enough to take it on.As in the earlier Total War games, there are essentially two distinctly different types of gameplay in Rome. There's the overarching turn-based campaign in which you conquer cities and provinces, make improvements, and move armies around the map as you expand your empire, and then there are the real-time battles in which you use tactics and maneuvers to crush your enemy in combat. After the helpful and informative tutorial campaign, you can tackle the main imperial campaign. You play as one of three powerful Roman families--the Julii, the Bruti, or the Scipii--attempting to increase the size and glory of Rome and shore up your faction's power and influence. As all three factions are Roman, there's literally no difference between them in terms of units and building types, though they do have different responsibilities. The Julii must deal with the Gauls and Germania to the north in a difficult, landlocked campaign. The Bruti are required to deal with the remnants of the Greek city-states and expand the empire to the southeast. And the Scipii are tasked with subduing Carthage, Rome's great nemesis to the southwest.At least, that's the principle goal of each faction. But there's a fourth, unplayable Roman faction, one that can influence your course during the campaign: the Roman senate. The senate will order you on missions, from blockading a hostile port or conquering a city (and perhaps exterminating the populace, depending on the level of enmity between Rome and the faction in question) to forging a trade deal or an alliance with a foreign faction. It's up to you whether you actually obey the order, as sometimes the senate will try to stretch you thin on purpose. If you carry the orders out successfully, you stand to gain a monetary reward, a useful new military unit, or influence in the senate. Failing to carry out missions earns the displeasure of the senate and affects your standing with that body. By and large, though, the senate missions help to focus the otherwise huge scope of the campaign--instead of being faced with the monolithic task of trying to conquer Europe, you can instead look forward to accomplishing a long series of short-term goals.It's helpful to perform senate missions because they can affect an improved feature in Rome: Total War--families. Each of the three Roman factions is essentially one huge family, and your generals and governors are related to one another by birth, marriage, or adoption. These are the leaders of your faction, and they all have traits--strengths and weaknesses--that define their abilities. A strong general may have an excellent command rating, but his disdain for bureaucracy would make him a poor governor. Meanwhile, an otherwise strong governor may have a dislike of farming, which would affect the agricultural output in the province he's in. But if your family members are selected to hold important senate posts, they'll gain influence and abilities once out of office. This introduces a limited role-playing component in the game, as you actually care about trying to further the careers of your family members so they can serve you better.In addition to traits, family members--not to mention your spies, assassins, and diplomats--can all attract retinues. These are the hangers-on who surround important people, such as advisors, mentors, bodyguards, lackeys, sycophants, and more. Each of these can affect your characters' abilities. For example, a wrestler can improve a character's influence (by being able to literally twist arms), as well as provide added protection against an assassination attempt. You can actually collect and trade retinue members among your family, so you can transfer them to where they're needed the most.You'll draw your faction's leaders from the family tree. Make sure not to kill off your heirs in battle.Families are also critical because only family members can serve as generals. You can assemble armies without a general, but they'll be poorly led and will likely fare badly in battle. But with a general, the army's fortune can change. A general with a high command ability is a powerful force in battle, as a well-led smaller force can defeat a poorly led larger force most of the time. On the other hand, the fact that generals are drawn from the ruling family can be dangerous, because you need to make sure there are future generations of leaders and generals. A disastrous battle can wipe out whole branches of the family tree, cutting down promising young sons before they can sire heirs. This can have a crippling effect later on in the campaign, when you find yourself short of qualified generals and governors with a huge empire to manage. It makes for an excellent incentive to try and preserve your generals, rather than treat them as easily replaceable fodder.Thankfully, when you're short of governors, your cities will be taken over by the "automanager," which is represented by an appointed official who runs the city in your name. You can give the automanager certain priorities, such as to follow a military or financial policy, and it will go about constructing the building and units required. (You can also turn on the automanage functionality in cities that do have governors, if you don't want to micromanage at all.) The computer is generally good at doing what you tell it to do, and this should appeal to players who don't want to spend a lot of time on the campaign map. But if you're a fan of grand strategy and want to control every detail, you'll want to make sure you have plenty of family members at your disposal.You can choose to autogenerate battle results or fight the battles personally. In most cases, it's easier and simpler to autogenerate the smaller fights.You can choose to autogenerate battle results or fight the battles personally. In most cases, it's easier and simpler to autogenerate the smaller fights.When you're not busy trying to crush your opponents, you can try to spy on, trade with, and subvert them. The diplomacy system has been completely overhauled since Medieval: Total War, and you now have a lot more options at your command. These include forming alliances, bullying your neighbors into becoming protectorates of Rome, and bargaining for trade rights. You can also dispatch spies and assassins to probe for weaknesses in enemy defenses, or to take out a key enemy general before a crucial battle. And in a nice twist, you can plant spies in your own cities, where they'll help keep unrest in check by acting as a secret police of sorts, rooting out the troublemakers. I definitly recommend this game to people who enjoy a good, long, legendary campain.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												On older games, you will often experience performance that is less than optimal given how modern hardware should be able to shred older titles. However the Steam version of Rome Total War Gold somehow manages to lower performance even further by an exponential level, to the point where you will experience single-digit FPS numbers on large battles. For whatever reason, this effect seems to be amplified even further on the Alexander expansion.Apparently this has something to do with the switch from Gamespy to Steam servers. Anyhow, the only reason to buy this on steam is for the multiplayer, which is almost completely dead anyway. Performance is absolutely unacceptable.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a strategy game.The spectacular graphics and extensive detail behind each character and race.Whether you choose to play as a Roman or a Gaul, each family member has their own traits and differences, so every new playthrough has it's own new experiences.The battles are utterly amazing, whether you're flanking your enemy with cavalry, using your archers to hold off twice your men, or bringing reinforcements that either you or an AI can control.Then there's the diplomatic side to it, you can put a spy in an enemy city in the hopes that when the time comes, they manage to open the gates for your men. Or, sending an assassin to kill an enemy captain, maybe send your diplomat to win over the enemy?However you choose to play the game, it's up to you. But it is definetely worth the price tag! 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I was the romano british, and most of europe was under my grasp. I had forged a strong alliance with the east and west roman empires, and most of the hordes had crumbled beneath my combined arms tactics. My graal knights ruled the world, and history was as it should be. Then the eastern roman empire decided I was making too much trade on londinum and landed there en masse, the same turn that the huns came out of hiding. The western roman empire, confused on what to do declared war on everything that breathed. Civilization crumbled again, and I will now have to spend another sixty hours piecing everything back together again.The game is a great strategy game, and the campaigns are fun (The modded ones are good fun as well) but for the love of god find a campaign AI upgrade.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Now superceded but a great game in it's own right - I immensely enjoyed playing the long  campaigns of all 3 familys in this game.    Each one plays a litttle differently to maintain your interest - and because of their location will have different strengths and weakness's.  Should you buy it? - Yes if you like action oriented strategy and tactics and or historical warfare.I like it enough to have bought it in boxes and from 2 different companies digitally as well. And it runs fine on most modern computer systems so you shouldn't need to break the bank on new hardware either.Of late (July 2015)  I have noticed a move back to this game from Rome II - with some saying they have dumbed the AI and gameplay down in the new one in favour of better graphics.  Ive put in 622 hours on it on steam.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2012
												There are probably hundreds of recommendations for Rome Total War, but I decided to write one as well. Rome Total War by far is one of the best strategy games to ever break into the market. Though the graphics are a little outdated, considering it first came out in 2004, the gameplay, unit selection, campaign, and my personal favorite, Multiplayer are outstanding. One of the best, if not the best game in the Total War series. I would recommend this to anyone who is a lover of Ancient Warfare, Ancient history, military history, and real time strategy games. Even if you dont' like any of those topics, play it anyway, because through this game one may sprout an interest in one of many subjects relating to this games history.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												My favorite Total War game and the game that actually got me into the series.I love the roman period.I have literally spent 1000's of hours on this game, probably completed the campaign more than 50 times, not including the 2 dlc's, that was well before steam. And apart from the graphics/resolution, a game spoiling bug (epic seige bug) and the quite boring building structure, compared to later games, this game is still my prefered TW game even over rome 2!This is a great game to get if you are a TW fan and want to play on a low spec laptop.It is not about the graphics like more modern TW games, for me it is the far more simpler strategy and building management that would make me suggest for people to buy this game.The building structure was quite simple as was the diplomacy, army management etc.. essentially, when you know what you are doing, maintaining an attacking flow and constant faction progression is a much easier task than R2 for instance.Perfect for playing when you don't exactly want to invest a whole amount of mental energy to a campaign, but want to succeed, and enjoy a great TW game.

You can play on a variety of sides during various skirmishes and all out battles all over Italy.The game in general is entirely reliant on combat and tactics. content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I know it says 7 minutes but I had the boxed version when I was younger and I have to say this is the STANDARD for Total War games, if not (older) strategy games. I am not saying this game is good for nostalgic reasons, I actually did enjoy this game because of how simple the map was yet how tactical the battles were, even with less units than the newer TW games. The game's map was smaller because the game is dated, and mainly for that reason I would get Rome 2 instead, because with a bigger map comes more diverse factions and units, more climate changes, and naval battles are not in this game, if I remember correctly (Though I hate them). Note: I love the city building in this game because of how many types of buildings there are, their simple and straightforward effects, and how it branches off to new things, and also I am pretty sure you can view your city in 3D, which is nice (Could be Medieval 2?)

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												One of the greatest games of all times- who doesn't want to conquer the world using Pigs you can set on fire? This game, is without a doubt, one of the greatest things total war invented, the variety of nations and paths you can take leaves you almost unable to stop. Try to conquer the known world, killing the gauls, the britons, the spaniards... etc, but we can't forget the parthians and their amazing pyjama warriors ;p Once you tire the singleplayer (normally after you have dominated the world at least a dozen times) you can try your hand at defeating other players on the multiplayer. I spent so many hours of my life dragging my friends with their laptops to my house to play all v all on this game... It was essentually who was the most devious or subtle one of us who won, always a challenge to be more cunning than the next. I found the best way to success was to use troops that blended into the map... so though they could be seen, they were'nt always acknowledged by my opponents... Though I may not have many hours in this game on steam, it was through the disk that I played a good thousand of hours on...

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Rome Total war is a rare breed. A realistic RTS game without the chaos of real life interfering with it. Historically, this game is fairly accurate, and the Roman fighting style lends itself to more user friendly battles. And here is where the game is such a drastic improvement on the previouse titles in the series.Organised ChaosWhether it is by phalanx or testeudo, the battles are a lot more organised than its predecessors. Battles are based on your ability to organise, coordinate and react to the adversity, more than the troops at your disposal. Gone are the morale sapping archers on the hill top and heavy cavalry charge from Medieval TW2 - Rome brings you a more balanced feel to the battle, even if it is elephants vs peasants.Macro, not micro managementWhat I like most about Rome (and where they seem to have strayed from the path in more recent releases) is that these are strategy simulations, not population management games. The management evironment is simple and straight forward, the interface is both familiar and intuititve while still giving you the ability to go into more detail if those damn peasants insist on revolting every turn.Rome is a great game to either pick up and play or delve into in for days on end. Rest assured there is a battle around every corner, usually where you least suspect it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Fun game, easy mechanics, but graphics alright...(it is an "old game")Campaign:Starting from 272 BC from 3 Roman factions (Brutii, Juli, Scipii) You start expanding and managing Your own empire, obeying The Senates requests and missions- breaking out wars and building alliances(you can overthrow The senate "S.P.Q.R." when you grow stronger and turn on all Your roman allies or continue fighting with them). Defeated factions become available for a new imperial campgain, in other words- new buildings, units, strategies.The campaign map is huge: covers entire Europe(except for the Northen regions), North Africa and little of east Azia and has over 50 provinces. Rome: Total War also has historical battles where You get to decide the outcome of it(normally good commanders lead their troops to victory, these battles are to judge Your skill and leadership to win with minimum casualties)Multiplayer:Up to 8 commanders in the battlefield, players can choose between scored resolution and last man standing modes, form teams or just go "every man for himself" A.K.A Free For All(FFA). The host chooses the battlemap, sets rules, and it is go time!Even though R:TW is old, it's still remarkable, and offers an enjoyable gameplay. It is the fact the You get to control a full army: from hundreds up to thousands of soldiers at Your disposal!

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												There is very little to say about the amazingness of this game. So instead I will put a recipe for pancakes.\Makes: 4 to 6 servingsTime: 20 minutesIt’s amazing how quickly you can whip up this batter.  Store it, covered, in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.  Adjust the consistency of the batter with either more milk or more flour as you like. Recipe from How to Cook Everything.2 cups all-purpose flour2 teaspoons baking powder1/2 teaspoon salt1 tablespoon sugar (optional)2 eggs11/2 to 2 cups milk2 optional tablespoons melted and cooled butter, plusunmelted butter for cooking, or use a neutral oil likegrapeseed or corn1. Heat a griddle or large skillet over medium-low heat while you make the batter.2. Mix together the dry ingredients. Beat the eggs into 11/2 cups of the milk, then stir in the 2 tablespoons cooled melted butter if you’re using it. Gently stir this mixture into the dry ingredients, mixing only enough to moisten the flour; don’t worry about a few lumps. If the batter seems thick, add a little more milk.3. Use a little butter or oil each time you add batter, unless your skillet is truly nonstick. When the butter foam subsides or the oil shimmers, ladle batter onto the griddle or skillet, making any size pancakes you like.  Adjust the heat as necessary; usually, the first batch will require higher heat than subsequent batches. The idea is to brown the bottom in 2 to 4 minutes, without burning it. Flip when bubbles appear in the center of the pancakes and the bottoms are cooked; they won’t hold together well until they’re ready.4. Cook until the second side is lightly browned, a couple more minutes, and serve or hold on an ovenproof plate in a 200°F oven for up to 15 minutes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2012
												ROMANES EUNT DOMUS?!Rome: Total War is what you play when you want to tell the Romans to go home, or vice versa.It's the third game in the Total War series, and the first to introduce the gameplay template it still uses today. Gone are the 2D battlefield models and Risk-style campaign map from the first two games, replaced with 3D models and a strategic map you can use to finely position units and armies. Gameplay revolves around managing your territory in a turn-based strategy mode and moving armies around the map to fight opposing armies and capture or defend settlements in a real time tactics mode.This particular entry is widely regarded as a classic, and with great value to boot. It can certainly suffice for people who can't afford or run the later games in the series. Unfortunately the game is optimized to run on only one CPU core, so newer computers might run into some trouble anyway. As this is still only the third game in the series, there are some things in later titles that are lacking in this one such as resolutions above 1600x1400. Something to keep in mind, at least.The Gold Edition comes with the Barbarian Invasion expansion that takes place during the fall of the Roman Empire, adding new factions and some new features such as hordes & religion; well worth playing after the base game. There's also a second expansion-slash-DLC available separately that lets you play as Alexander the Great, and it's required for some of the more popular mods to run.The vanilla game is a good way to get the hang of things, but from the disorganized battle lines to the historical inaccuracy I wouldn't recommend playing for any extended period of time. To wit: the Greek city-states form one faction (just one) while Rome is divided into three gens that each get their own faction. Egypt, meanwhile, looks like it walked out of a timewarp from 1000 BC instead of the Ptolemaic empire it was at the time of Rome's ascent.There's a number of mods that overhaul the game to fix these issues and more, including (nominally) improved AI, which has always been a weakpoint of the TW series - with the exception of the first two games, which used Risk-style troop movement that's easier for AI to understand. Two of the most popular RTW mods include Rome Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum, the former being a general overhaul of the game and the latter being much more realism-focused to the point of near simulation.I'd recommend this as an entry point into Total War for people on a budget. It's probably better than Rome II at any rate; even with the many improvements that game's had since its disastrous launch it's still a game about ancient warfare that uses an engine Creative Assembly intended for Napoleonic warfare.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												 Slightly out of date now especially with its successors release. However a great introduction to the series and this edition contains a huge amount of gameplay. The graphics are quite dated given the standard of the rest of the series nowadays but still enjoyable. While they spend the next year working out all the bugs on Rome: Total War 2 I would strongly recommend getting a taste for the game through this edition by which time Rome Total War 2 will be patched enough that it will be a superlative game. In the meantime you will easily lose yourself in this game and develop a real taste for the series in general.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Possibly the best TW game on the market. It may just be me viewing it through nostalgia-tinted lenses, but this game definitelly surpassed the competition in my book.Pros:- Good unit variety, building variety, and so on.- Far more colorful and vibrant than later entries.- Good variety of civilizations.- Decent dificulty curve.- Replayable to almost infinity due to variety of strategems and civilizations.- Decent modding community and re-works through dedicated websites.Cons:- Realism slightly lacking.- Some balance issues in multiplayer (barbarians lack morale, phalanx beats any other unit one-on-one etc.).- Poor diplomacy.- Community has partially moved on to Medieval II and later, meaning less mods and reworks to add replayability that    otherwise.- Graphics slightly dated.In short, the game has much to reccomend it. The main complaint I find is that the game hasn't aged well compared to others, that the graphics are out of date etc. While some have a point, the old graphics have a certain charm and don't detract from the gameplay one bit. In fact, I take that as a point in their favor as it means that older systems can run the game without frying from the effort.Buy it. You won't regret it one bit.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Possibly my favourite game. I played the White Label version to death a few years ago. I was quite happy to see that they added Barbarian Invasion to this as well. Rome Total War combines a turn-based strategy world map with real time battle screen. The battles are the best part of the game so if you're more inclined to staring at maps and managing economics  I recommend looking at the Paradox games like Crusader Kings or Hearts of Iron.This game is considered one of the better in the series and the graphics aren't too bad for an eleven year old game. My favourite part of this game is the custom battles. A phalanx of Spartans vs 1000 Roman peasants, who wins?If you're not sold on the dated graphics you can always download a mod or go for one of the newer games. However Creative Assembly managed to make every entry after Medieval 2 with a new engine. Since then the releases have been a bit hit or miss. Rome 2 had an incredibly poor launch thanks to a variety of bugs and removed features.So if you want a fun strategy game I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												I came, I saw, I conquered!Played it since my teen years, bought and played it again. Choose a Roman family, rise in status, fight barbarians, and seize power in Rome herself. Or you could be a barbarian heathen. Easily one of my favorite games in the series and one of the best RTS games of all time. The only problem perhaps is the autoresolve battle AI seems to leave a lot to be desired. However; if you wanted a turn based game I recommend The Republic of Rome Tabletop game (playable by your lonesome but better with friends you aren't afraid to lose) or your favorite Civilization. The Historical inaccuracy of certain aspects is also fairly blatant but it is forgiven due to the game being more about cinematic sword and sandal warfare than a rough simulation of historical events for that I recommend something by Paradox Interactive.The game's strenghts lie in it's great battle system and it's fascinating overworld of intrigue. If you want a hardcore tactics game it can be that but there is also an arcade mode for people who just want to watch the sword fights but do not wish to get heavily involved in tactical movement.This is a game I could recommend for anyone with even a passing interest in this period in history. The phoenicians are waiting to meet you on the field of battle.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Very good game, probably my favorite in the total war series.Pros:- Good UI makes for easy battlefield control of large armies. - Many different factions to play as with very diverse units in each. - Different campaign versions both long and short for casual or hardcore players. - Good volume of realism, armies rout and react to surprise attacks and battlefield conditions. Cons:- AI is not a very effective commander, makes for easy victories due to lack of tactical challenge against even armies. - Squalor mechanic is slightly broken meaning that cities become more rebellious despite good quality living standards. - Diplomacy is next to pointless other than for trade agreements, alliances very rarely offer any military benefits. Overall this is a great game and its only minor things that prevent this game from being perfect. I'd rate this 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I hadn't played any Total War games until I bought this one. After downloading and running it I went through a tutorial that taught me how to push buttons, and then I began the campaign. I started as the great Roman house of Julli, and began my great campaign. After pushing north to the alps, driving out the Gauls, I made peace with the nearby empires. The Gauls had been raiding me on occasion, and I had always beaten them back. Things seemed to be going well, until I asked to buy a city the Gauls owned. Now, of course, I offered a fair price. It was an incredible price, in fact, but they denied it. I offered again, with even more money and goods, and again they denied. This was the last straw. How DARE they deny me?! Don't they know who WON all those wars? I then decided that I had had enough of these ancient Frenchmen who dared to think they are equal to us great Romans. I not only wanted to teach them a lesson; I wanted them gone. So thus, the Great Gaul Genocide began.It was a truly incredible campaign. Several new armies were raised. All traces of Gaul in the east were annihilated first, and a great push into the west began. Whenever I captured a city I was given the option to either occupy it as it was, enslave half the people and disperse them among my empire, or slaughter 3/4 of the people in the settlement. Naturally, I chose the latter. My goal was elimination. Death to all those barbarians who dared to have national pride. I pushed into the Gaul empire, taking city after city. The enemy had a bigger empire, perhaps, but mine was far stronger. Our great Roman soldiers killed all in their path. Despite a stumbling point where one Gaul army managed to defeat mine and save their city, two new armies took its place. The massive campaign wore on until, at last, the final Gaul stronghold fell. The people were slaughtered, and nothing remained of the once great empire.  I had kept a running body count as the genocide wore on. The final results were:Gaul Soldiers killed: 3,659Gaul Civilians killed: 33,689Total Barbarian Gauls killed (citizens and soldiers): 37,339Brave Roman soldiers lost: 1,258Final body count: 38,597 people dead. It was only after the genocide was over that I realized I'd forgotten why I was mad at them in the first place. Hmm...it was something about a city...10/10 would genocide again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												I must begin by stating that Rome: Total War was the first and so far the only Total War game I have played.Total War is an exciting and very cerebral strategy game, that tasks you with not only rallying your troops and commanding them in battle but also governing your multiple cities along with it's inhabitants and the political relationships with other factions.The main campaign plays like a turn-based board game, where each player makes their choices and then skips, allowing others to make their moves. The objective is to take over the world.Managing your settlements is the slow paced portion of the game but still varied, as you need to satisfy your people while also recruting and positioning your military in order to accomplish your goals. You also need to be wary of what other factions feel towards you and your movements, as having allies might make a critical difference.When your troops meet other troops in the battlefield, whether it was you who attacked or your opponent is when there is the option to combat them manually. You take control of large armies, going up to to the hundreds or thousands depending or your settings. Controlling this massive number of soldiers is easy and intuitive and the variety of available units allow the combat system to provide you with multiple options. Each unit has its strenghs and purposes and the overall combination of troops you decide to take to battle make all the difference in the world.I can't recommend this game enough to any player who enjoys strategy or military games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												I bought this then-cutting-edge game back when it was released in 2004. I'd seen it advertised some months before that on a TV series that used its engine wherein two teams competed against each other to win an historical battle. That whetted my appetite enormously. When I bought it, I not only spent countless hours playing but also played its add-ons (Barbarian Invasion and Alexander).To me Rome: Total War was the best of the Total War series - a balance between the old 2D strategy of Medieval: Total War and the increasingly eye-candy iterations that came thereafter (though I think Medieval 2: Total War was also very good).Add to this the fact that Rome has more mods than any other in that series (and with more diversity of setting/theme) and you have a game that is highly replayable. I still dip into it after 11 years of owning it! Rome forums still remain populated after all this time, and mods are still being developed for it. That speaks volumes.I've had the pleasure of being a RTW modder myself which has only added to the great joy this game has brought. Give it a go. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												I spend a majority of my strategy gaming with two games: Rome: Total War and Civilization V (I have maybe 250+ hours offline in RTW). Why do I mention this? Because I have to say that while Civ V is a better game (though not by much), I have never found a game more masterfully put together than Rome: Total War. You might be the nicest person ever, but by the end of a campaign you might as well be ranked as the world's #1 sociopath, for you will be driven to crush every rebellion and consolidate the world under the mighty grip of your imperium. The aesthetic, feel, music, all for the glory of arguably the greatest empire ever created is emulated to absolute perfection.And that's 10 YEARS after the game has been released. The most epic, enthralling, massive strategy game you'll ever get your hands on.Only issues involve possible compatibility problems. Other than that, you're paying $10 for hundreds of hours of triumphant conquest. An absolute must buy.

It is old so don't expect much features or awesome graphics.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2012
												ROMANES EUNT DOMUS?!Rome: Total War is what you play when you want to tell the Romans to go home, or vice versa.It's the third game in the Total War series, and the first to introduce the gameplay template it still uses today. Gone are the 2D battlefield models and Risk-style campaign map from the first two games, replaced with 3D models and a strategic map you can use to finely position units and armies. Gameplay revolves around managing your territory in a turn-based strategy mode and moving armies around the map to fight opposing armies and capture or defend settlements in a real time tactics mode.This particular entry is widely regarded as a classic, and with great value to boot. It can certainly suffice for people who can't afford or run the later games in the series. Unfortunately the game is optimized to run on only one CPU core, so newer computers might run into some trouble anyway. As this is still only the third game in the series, there are some things in later titles that are lacking in this one such as resolutions above 1600x1400. Something to keep in mind, at least.The Gold Edition comes with the Barbarian Invasion expansion that takes place during the fall of the Roman Empire, adding new factions and some new features such as hordes & religion; well worth playing after the base game. There's also a second expansion-slash-DLC available separately that lets you play as Alexander the Great, and it's required for some of the more popular mods to run.The vanilla game is a good way to get the hang of things, but from the disorganized battle lines to the historical inaccuracy I wouldn't recommend playing for any extended period of time. To wit: the Greek city-states form one faction (just one) while Rome is divided into three gens that each get their own faction. Egypt, meanwhile, looks like it walked out of a timewarp from 1000 BC instead of the Ptolemaic empire it was at the time of Rome's ascent.There's a number of mods that overhaul the game to fix these issues and more, including (nominally) improved AI, which has always been a weakpoint of the TW series - with the exception of the first two games, which used Risk-style troop movement that's easier for AI to understand. Two of the most popular RTW mods include Rome Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum, the former being a general overhaul of the game and the latter being much more realism-focused to the point of near simulation.I'd recommend this as an entry point into Total War for people on a budget. It's probably better than Rome II at any rate; even with the many improvements that game's had since its disastrous launch it's still a game about ancient warfare that uses an engine Creative Assembly intended for Napoleonic warfare.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												Where do I begin? The soothing music is soothing, the epic battles are epic. The Syrians are the Syrians, sadly Scotia does not feature.I recommend to start as the Julii, the Gauls are a relatively easy opponent, and they fly the well-known Roman Red colour. The Brutii are fun, but you're up against tougher opposition, in the form of Pontus...Feckin' Pontus... But, the Scipii, in my opinion are the hardest. Lemme explain: Your main enemy is Carthage, they have War Elephants, you'll also be mainly situated in the North African desert, Arid climate does not help trade or pop growth.Anyway, 10/10 Game, one of my favorites, i may even prefer it over Med II Total War.

content:

												Never bothered with Total War games. Then I decided to pick up a copy of Rome 2 to see why everyone was getting massive hard ons about it. I thought that was great and all but I wanted to try the other games.MY GOD! THIS IS WHAT I'VE BEEN MISSING OUT ON!? Sure the graphics and animations are 10 years old but the game itself has so much to offer. It even has my favourite period of history: West and East Roman Empires, this is much more challenging, complex, and tactical than Rome 2, even its soundtrack is better. This requries actual skill to succeed, you really need to think of the consquences of your actions and its effects on your empire.Despite its age, Rome has easily become my second favourite RTS (Wargame comes first) I know I will be playing this more than Rome 2. I still can't get over the fact that I didn't get this eariler, I have a lot of catching up to do on the other Total War titles.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												I must begin by stating that Rome: Total War was the first and so far the only Total War game I have played.Total War is an exciting and very cerebral strategy game, that tasks you with not only rallying your troops and commanding them in battle but also governing your multiple cities along with it's inhabitants and the political relationships with other factions.The main campaign plays like a turn-based board game, where each player makes their choices and then skips, allowing others to make their moves. The objective is to take over the world.Managing your settlements is the slow paced portion of the game but still varied, as you need to satisfy your people while also recruting and positioning your military in order to accomplish your goals. You also need to be wary of what other factions feel towards you and your movements, as having allies might make a critical difference.When your troops meet other troops in the battlefield, whether it was you who attacked or your opponent is when there is the option to combat them manually. You take control of large armies, going up to to the hundreds or thousands depending or your settings. Controlling this massive number of soldiers is easy and intuitive and the variety of available units allow the combat system to provide you with multiple options. Each unit has its strenghs and purposes and the overall combination of troops you decide to take to battle make all the difference in the world.I can't recommend this game enough to any player who enjoys strategy or military games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2012
												ROMANES EUNT DOMUS?!Rome: Total War is what you play when you want to tell the Romans to go home, or vice versa.It's the third game in the Total War series, and the first to introduce the gameplay template it still uses today. Gone are the 2D battlefield models and Risk-style campaign map from the first two games, replaced with 3D models and a strategic map you can use to finely position units and armies. Gameplay revolves around managing your territory in a turn-based strategy mode and moving armies around the map to fight opposing armies and capture or defend settlements in a real time tactics mode.This particular entry is widely regarded as a classic, and with great value to boot. It can certainly suffice for people who can't afford or run the later games in the series. Unfortunately the game is optimized to run on only one CPU core, so newer computers might run into some trouble anyway. As this is still only the third game in the series, there are some things in later titles that are lacking in this one such as resolutions above 1600x1400. Something to keep in mind, at least.The Gold Edition comes with the Barbarian Invasion expansion that takes place during the fall of the Roman Empire, adding new factions and some new features such as hordes & religion; well worth playing after the base game. There's also a second expansion-slash-DLC available separately that lets you play as Alexander the Great, and it's required for some of the more popular mods to run.The vanilla game is a good way to get the hang of things, but from the disorganized battle lines to the historical inaccuracy I wouldn't recommend playing for any extended period of time. To wit: the Greek city-states form one faction (just one) while Rome is divided into three gens that each get their own faction. Egypt, meanwhile, looks like it walked out of a timewarp from 1000 BC instead of the Ptolemaic empire it was at the time of Rome's ascent.There's a number of mods that overhaul the game to fix these issues and more, including (nominally) improved AI, which has always been a weakpoint of the TW series - with the exception of the first two games, which used Risk-style troop movement that's easier for AI to understand. Two of the most popular RTW mods include Rome Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum, the former being a general overhaul of the game and the latter being much more realism-focused to the point of near simulation.I'd recommend this as an entry point into Total War for people on a budget. It's probably better than Rome II at any rate; even with the many improvements that game's had since its disastrous launch it's still a game about ancient warfare that uses an engine Creative Assembly intended for Napoleonic warfare.

Posted: January 16, 2015
												This game hits right on the target for RTS games. It has a turn based campaign in which you create massive armies and manage settlements. Then when two armies collide (whether that be an seige or field battle) the real fun begins you can play battles with thousands of soldiers slugging it out. The different factions have huge differences in which you have to play. Romans have superb heavy infantry which can tackle most other infantry but lack cavalry. The Greeks have phalanx that buckle down enemy infantry so your cavalry can finish the job. And the barbarian have cool unique units like the druids and fanatics. This game is very polished and is better than all the other games in the series and i have played all but the first two (rome 2 is on my other account). Me and my friend love playing battles (even though he spams phants and  sacred band). I would recommend this game to anyone who plays RTS!

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												I spend a majority of my strategy gaming with two games: Rome: Total War and Civilization V (I have maybe 250+ hours offline in RTW). Why do I mention this? Because I have to say that while Civ V is a better game (though not by much), I have never found a game more masterfully put together than Rome: Total War. You might be the nicest person ever, but by the end of a campaign you might as well be ranked as the world's #1 sociopath, for you will be driven to crush every rebellion and consolidate the world under the mighty grip of your imperium. The aesthetic, feel, music, all for the glory of arguably the greatest empire ever created is emulated to absolute perfection.And that's 10 YEARS after the game has been released. The most epic, enthralling, massive strategy game you'll ever get your hands on.Only issues involve possible compatibility problems. Other than that, you're paying $10 for hundreds of hours of triumphant conquest. An absolute must buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												This game is on my Top 5 Games of All Time List.Let's start with the presentation. This Games graphics are out dated, but the attention to detail and polish are abundant. Nothing was more satisfying then watching my cavalry charge send individual men flying. The world map is kind of bland, but you have a pretty good idea of what the terrain is. All of the cities are (or were) real cities, and many you may already know of. This game is a very well researched game. There are many historical troop types and landmarks. I can't even imagine how much time was put in to making this game as historically accurate as possible.Overall, this is a well-presented game.Now let's look at gameplay. This games battle system is hands down the best I have seen in any RTS ever. The attention to detail is astounding. Certain troops counter others, this is in other games. However, different formations and tactics can turn the tables on your so-called counters. You can be a regular Cesar if you play your cards right. The AI is not the sharpest tool in the shed, especially when it comes to troop movement. I have missed a table-turning oppurtunity in many a battle due to a units slow response or incorrect followthrough of an order. It could be said that this makes the game more realistic, but that doesn't make it any less frustrating. The game can be played in single or multiplayer player mode. Single player has three functions: Campaign, Custom battles, and Historical battles. The Campaign can be played as one of the three Roman factions at first and later other factions. Not every faction can be played as-at least not in th vanilla-which is a shame as many unique factions were left out. The campaign takes place over a world map as you and the other factions take turns building and managing an empire. The campaign is extremely immersive. Players personalities are reflected in how they play the game. I can be impatient, but I also am a procrastinator. As a result, I would impatiently blitz one enemy, then stand around repelling the attacks of another. The goals of the game are dependent on what type of campaign tou chose. A short one has small goals while a long one has large. Overall the campaign is the best part of the game. The custom battle option is fun for experimenting with new tactics or just goofing around. It is not something you will spend a ton of time on though. The Historical battles are just that, battles from history. They put you in the shoes of real ancient commanders in battles that actually took place. They're fun, but not very replayable. The multiplayer is the second best function of the game. It allows you to play online in battles with other players. The type of battles vary, from sieges to free-for-alls. There are even some historical battles exclusive to multiplayer. Overall, the multiplayer is great for when you want a change of pace.Over all, this game has a good presentation, pays attention to detail, and is highly immersive, the best ten bucks you'll ever spend. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												I definetly loved this game. It was revolutionary at the time and is still considered one of the best total wars to date. It is mostly balanced and when it's not it's usually just the overpricing of certain units. The community is full of skilled players which is a pro and a con. Many players may struggle to get into the game because of that fact, but if you practice enough and look up some strategy guides then you can rek face. I felt that no army was super under-powered or super over-powered and that anyone could be good with any faction. Now I'm going to talk a bit more about the cons. One of my major cons is that some factions do not get that many units. In campaign this may be OK but in multiplayer it can make some factions harder to play as. Next con is, well it's old. I'm not complaining about graphics, I'm more complaining about limitations. Battles above five thousand are laggy and hard to play. Also the campaign is hard if you don't look up even one strategy guide. It's confusing and sometimes you feel like you don't know what to do. They give you some tips that aren't neccessarily helpful. I remember having to restart the game as the brutii often because it's that hard. You can end up having built up a large debt. And my final complaint is diplomacy. Oh god the diplomacy. The diplomacy is awful. I remember gaul asking me for trade rights, me accepting, and then they attack me. Also, I have a friend who was attacking the last city of dacia. Dacia had a ton of money and he had accept or we will attack, in exchange for ten thousand denarii. Dacia refused and got obliterated. Stingy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Also, Gaul in my most recent Brutii playthrough said "give us 500 denarii or we will attack" and I just gave it to them. Keep in mind that the julii is currently making them their ♥♥♥♥♥. Then I was like, "Hey, want map information? Just give us 10,000 denarii." Gaul counter offered with "Give us 550 denarii every turn for two turns or we'll attack." and I was like "♥♥♥♥ you!" and then Gaul went to go threaten the rest of rome. Bare in mind that they haven't attacked yet.My final score is 9/10 for the game. It struggles a bit, but for the time it was made it was amazing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Possibly my favourite game. I played the White Label version to death a few years ago. I was quite happy to see that they added Barbarian Invasion to this as well. Rome Total War combines a turn-based strategy world map with real time battle screen. The battles are the best part of the game so if you're more inclined to staring at maps and managing economics  I recommend looking at the Paradox games like Crusader Kings or Hearts of Iron.This game is considered one of the better in the series and the graphics aren't too bad for an eleven year old game. My favourite part of this game is the custom battles. A phalanx of Spartans vs 1000 Roman peasants, who wins?If you're not sold on the dated graphics you can always download a mod or go for one of the newer games. However Creative Assembly managed to make every entry after Medieval 2 with a new engine. Since then the releases have been a bit hit or miss. Rome 2 had an incredibly poor launch thanks to a variety of bugs and removed features.So if you want a fun strategy game I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Rome: Total War is an excellent game. It allows you to take control of one of the three houses of rome (And other civs as well later) and pits you against others, you have to get your leaders into senates, conduct trade deals and manage provinces. You also have to manage the affairs of your family, whether or not your daughter will marry so and so, and if one of them dies of old age. It's a horrible feeling, that, especially when it's your leader who dies, and you are left lost, trying to find a Heir for when it happens again, moving your main body of the army under someone elses control. The battles are realistic, your men sometimes disobeying you, and having emotions of their own. If you are losing, they may run away, elephants and wolves will also freak them out. Sometimes one or two men will even disobey one of your orders, getting themselves killed, every loss you take is something you actually feel, as you must keep your army maintained and happy, keep your cities from rioting. It is not, however, impossible to play. I am doing it an injustice with how hard I am making it sound, it is truly an amazing game, and earns a good 9/10.

												Still the same pros&cons as the rest of the Total War series : halway between strategy game and cinema, entertaining but inadapted to challenging objectives. Note that this game has lots of user mods, with a community which is still lively. Therefore this is an interesting alternative to Rome II or any more recent Total War title if your computer sucks, if you're poor, or if you just don't like their new engine (I don't). The price to pay in term of features and gameplay richness is minimal.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Haven’t played this since it was sold on CD. Bought on steam for 3 dollarsJoin 2v2 with friendFriend wants to play as barbariansI refuse; a true roman would join the legionWe play as rome v barbariansHe brings a balanced force including war machines and skirmishersI bring a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of legionary cohortsI also point up a maxed out praetorian cohort; it costs more than 3 legionary cohortsIs it cost effective? I assume not. Yolo, I bring it anywaysDuring deployment we start at opposite ends of our sideWe accidentally start the battle early; we have not consolidated our forcesThe barbarians deploy about 2/3 of their forces opposite me with a blocking force against my teammateMy unsupported legionnaires are being overrun by the barbarian hordesMy teammate is bulldozing through the blocking force opposing him and rushing to my aidCan I survive long enough?I decide to commit my reserve - the praetorians - to sacrifice their lives for timePRAETORIANS, HOLD THE LINE AS LONG AS NECESSARY!The praetorians are having none of thisThey singlehandedly stabilize my lineBy the end of the battle over 900 of my 1500 men will be dead. Many others will have retreatedOnly 4 of 80 praetorians will dieThe literal last act of the battle was the infantry praetorians chasing down a mounted barbarian warlord and chopping him upI mouse over their status before the battle ends - they have been fighting about 2/3 of the battle, and charging up and down the field. Most of my other units are badly mauled, have low morale, and are exhausted“eager, warmed up, motivated by presence of general”ROMA VICTOR 10/10 would slaughter barbarians for the glory of rome again

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												My time playing this game.-Starts as the Julii-Makes a strong army-Invades the north declares war on Gaul-Gaul counter attacks but fails-Pushes towards west but fails-Gaul ambushes and destroy the main part of my army -Retreats quickly-Gaul chases the army-Army gets backup and pushes Gaul -Becomes ally with Briton to fight the Gauls-Briton betrays me and attack with 1277 troops-Backup arrives to retake Patavium from Arretium my capital-Declares war on Briton and pushes them to Luvavum-Macedon declares Thrace my ally-Declare war on Macedon-Attack Macedonian troops on the path to my city-600 romans vs 450 macedons-Macedon wins and damages my army very badly-Backup arrives from Luvavum-Im now fighting a war with 4 fronts-West(Gauls) north and east(Britons) and Southeast(Macedon)-Rebuild my grand army -Pushes Briton and Macedon-Briton starts guerilla warfare against me-Briton uses a strategy of hit and run which makes Macedon even stronger while I grow weaker-House of Brutii sends help and attacks Macedon from the south and North-Macedon cant fight me for now I have to rebuild my army quickly-Battle of Aemona begins-1000 Romans vs 600 Britons-Reclaims the city-Battle of Alessia begins-1000 Romans vs 500 Britons and 300 Gauls-I win the battle of Alessia making a Roman stronghold in France-Rebels starts fighting me with Macedon-Macedon,Rebels,Briton and Gauls are now fighting me at all sides but south-Gaul now surrounds my Grand army -Grand army losing numbers every turn -Gaul does the same strategy as Briton, Guerilla warfare and hit n' run-Army are now fighting at all sides except south-Damage economy,morale,numbers going down and riots at Patavium-Brutii and Scipii comes to help-Ceasefire with Macedon(betray them later c;)Im still not yet done with this game but its really funI rate it 10/10

Rome has very good unit, but i think that the Spartans are the strongest (rightfull, thouh) This game is certainly worth 4€ and if you worry about graphics, they aren't great for sure, but perfect for the genre and not too intensive so playable for more people than ROME II. I recommend this version above Total War Rome II.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												R:TW is a great strategy game, a grand strategy from the classics. It's pretty sophisticated for it's time, but since we have other strategy games, this is just a cakewalk, that is, if you're a stategist.Rome Total War ♥♥♥♥♥slaps Rome Total War 2, reason is, they completely released an unfinished game. Rome Total War was perfect, now they're just milking it of Rome Total War 2, anyways.Goodies:Rome Total War has amazing features, great units and other things. It takes the definition of strategy and slaps it right into your face. Now as you can see, my hours aren't any compared to others, (90% of the time I was rekting skrubs on multiplayer.)This is an amazing game, a real classic, if you had anyone that played this on it's release (me), it's a ♥♥♥♥ing classic game compared to the modern ones. It's great build kept me glued to it for hours on the box set back in 2006, and was a real game changer and introduction to strategy, like Europa Universalis, it's a great series, but it's "new" and "improved" games of 2013-2015 are killing it.Bad:There's a few glitches, and it tends to get boring if you don't find the.. -uhm- "right" scenario, skirmish, etc. to do.9.4/10Reason why: Classic game, amazing graphics for it's time, all-around great historical precision. Just a few annoying glitches like invincible Gauls. (Those that can take 500+ arrows surrounded by archers, and walk away with no damaged soldiers)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Rome Total War was the first game that I was ever obsessed with, being early in high school when it came out in 2004. I actually first saw the game engine on the History Channel’s show Decisive Battles, which used the game to depict the Battle of Cannae, among others.The slaughter that can be witnessed and commanded on the RTS battlefield in this game came at a pivotal time, when Lord of the Rings rewrote the book on grand fantasy movies. You saw these huge battles on screen in movies, and now you could command them yourself.From experience the central mechanics of a game obviously must grab you to hold interest, but I also believe that the little details can be just as important in showing the player how much the developers love their work. Those that struck me in this game were the hilarious descriptions and attributes of the generals, which adds flesh to the polygons you command. Here you could find that your general could be a bold Caesar, or an insane Caligula (literally one of the attributes can describe a character as painting his butt blue and running around the palace naked). These attributes can affect what your generals say in their speeches before a battle; I would always make insane generals my frontline commanders, just so I could hear them say ridiculous things before a battle. The game is fun, has plenty charm, and an epic soundtrack; still plenty of bugs, but they can be worked around. Try roleplaying your generals in battle, and your faction leader in the campaign map based upon their respective attributes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Good, ol' (10 year old to be exact) Total War, strategy.   Graphics look like they were designed in 2004... In case you were wondering, this game was released September 22, 2004.   Gameplay is awesome. That is what makes, Rome: Total War, so fun! The strategy system in this game is awesome. So many cool details to this game.   Preformance... well, assuming that you don't use any software made before Windows 2000 (I think I can safely make this assumption) this game runs perfectly.   The sound of this game is great. Very lively and realistic.   Controls are standard, no controller support.   Playtime? Well, that is up to you. If you get bored of strategy easily, you won't last over 10 hours, but if you like strategy, you'll play through the campaign a few times and play with your friends (15+ Hours)   Personally, I love this game, despite NOT being a lover of all things strategy related. Get this game, on sale, or not.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Rome: Total War is a great game. You know this game came out in 2004 and twelve years later this game managed to heavily impress me. From the small part of diplomatic relations to the absolute massive battle scenes, the game just immediately sucked me in. Now the Total War games had never really been a big thing to me up until this moment so I was just a bit dubious about how much this game would appeal to me, but I am a history buff and I was trying to find a way to spend the summer so I picked it up during the sale. What I found was an actually really good game that managed to combine the turn base parts with the real time strategy. The game as said is split into two types of strategy. The first part is map screen. From here you manage your settlements and your armies. You can upgrade your towns and recruit new units. From here you can also send out your diplomats to other factions in order to institute trade agreements and forge alliances for wars. The diplomats have actually quite a bit that they can discuss with the other factions. You can make demands such has making them hand over a territory or you can create a trade agreement that can help your income or just allow them military access to other parts of the world. Another thing that impressed me is that they can reject your offer and make counter offers. This really does feel like an actual negotiation rather than just a basic “I declare peace or war thing.” One thing I’m going to say though is that there is a severe problem with the lack of anything to really during peace time. In the end though the map screen is fantastic turn based strategy. Now as for the actual battle screens it is one the greatest parts of the game. The sieges and the battles are just so massive that it is impossible to be swept away by it. The fights aren’t too complicated. It doesn’t take long to figure the strengths and weaknesses and of each unit. Just know when to charge and how to flank the enemy and that’s rather easy to pick up. What makes it really work though is just the basic ability to pause the game and figure out your positions and where each unit should go. This takes a lot the panicking and stress out of other strategies that usually takes me out of most strategy games. The units are widely varied and it is rather cool to see the progress of your units to much more powerful troops.In the end what really sells the game is just the absolute scale it has. The game just feels massive and every advancement you do makes you feel more powerful. Some might say that the effects don’t look good and to those people I say they need to shut it. The game looked amazing back in the day and still looks line today. I don’t care if we can’t see every pimple on the soldiers they look fine. As for the multiplayer I don’t know what it’s like. I am not interested in it, but if you are then check it out. Rome: Total War is a game that everyone should check out if you are interested in history or if you think you might be interested in the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Having played the Total War series since the original Shogun, including the newer installments, Rome: Total War still stands as the one I believe is best.The graphics are certainly a bit dated, but even then they aren't horrible. The gameplay however is where this game really stood apart. The factions felt much more significant than a lot of the other games, while also not feeling TOO different, so it feels like you're fighting on equal terms more or less. Got a choice of quite a lot of factions, but the map itself isn't overloaded with different forces, and you're able to play all of them yourself once unlocking them, something they stopped allowing in later installments.Then one thing that I really like in this game, which I believe only showed up in Rome and Medieval 2 is the idea that your Captains (the leader of armies without Generals) can actually be adopted into your family and made a full on General for their accomplishments. Such a nice feature, as if you have an army going around and doing really well, that Captain deserves recognition. In general I liked the family tree system as well. Medieval 2 had a lot of this, but I felt got too bogged down by the religion system, whereas Rome has no such drawbacks to me.Overall I'd rate this game very highly, especially if you enjoy the Total War series. Bought it on Steam just so I wouldn't need to keep breaking out my old disc to play it, which is why the relatively low playtime.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Where to begin...Total War series, never a letdown but for some reason: this game's stability on Windows 7 has decreased horribly with updates. Even LESS optimized. PC is a Win7-64bit with all the bells and whistles and up-to-date drivers but yet the performance of the game stutters and suffers after about an hour in play to where it takes about 20 seconds to click a menu button. Googling some updates or at least some methods to try to solve this problem...no results. I'm honestly disappointed at how badly optimized this game is for Win7. Your experience may vary.Good - Total War series. Everything you ever wanted to be the ruler of Rome and pounding barbarians into dust while bowing to the Senate.-Unit scale is ridiculously well imagined and with proper planning - you can have some pretty large battles.-All the mods you could shake a stick at in Workshop or mod communities.-Replay value for each race/city is phenomenal.Bad- Badly optimized for Win7- Random stutters and crash-to-black. Save often.- With no balance mods, it's pretty easy for the micromanage to get out of hand to where you need to hire and fire peasants to transfer population from one city to another. Do your reading and listen to the advice on how to manage LARGE cities.Oldie but good but buyer beware. Be prepared to suffer a bit.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												*WARNING : LONG (But detailed) REVIEWWhere to start with Rome Total War? This game is like Sid Meier’s Civilization but more focused on , as the title would suggest , Total War. So, enough beating around the bush.ProsThis game is absolute genius. Its historically accurate , apart from the part when you , the player , take 100 percent of the area near Rome. The game notifies you when something like a flood or the Pompeii eruption occurs around the same time (I have no clue if Pompeii makes an appearance in the game. I've never gotten far enough). Another great part are the wars. There are , I believe , 3 types of fighting : Army to Army , Army to Town or City , and Fleet to Fleet. Army to Army is a standard type of fighting. Two armies on opposite sides of a field where there will be a fight to the death. This is challenging for me due to all the open space but to others it may be easier. Army to Town or City is where an army is trying to take a town or city by either maintaining a successful siege , starving the enemies inside, or forcefully invading by making Siege Towers , Ladders , Rams , and / or other breaching equipment. Either way , If successful , the army and their faction will then take and rule the captured city. Technically this is a con but , Fleet to Fleet is just borderline impossible , at least for me. In this type of battle, two fleets fight each other on the unrelenting sea. This can be especially dangerous if your ship attacked is a transport ship carrying YOUR ABSOLUTE BEST TROOPS. If this transport ship loses the battle , every man aboard will die. However , there is a fantastic feeling when you successfully take down an army , general , town , or even 1 of 20 factions. ConsThis game is anything but perfect. For starters , the battle screen. Before each battle , a screen pops up describing the soon starting skirmish along with 3 buttons : Flee and Retreat , Auto Resolve Battle , or Go to Battle Screen and fight the enemy yourself. Tip : Pick Auto Resolve. Fleeing is for Benito Mussolini and good luck trying to figure out the Battle Screen controls. The camera is awful. If you want to move the camera right there is a chance that you could end up looking at the ground. Along with that , you cant simply tell your archers to fire on an enemy. There's this whole process of moving them into position and it's just not worth it. Using a faulty controller to play Mortal Kombat while making a space station in Kerbal Space Program with your toes is easier than taking on an army. Its hard to explain but don't fight in the battles. Another con is the fact that the game goes through almost phases. One minute you have more generals than any other faction with more gold than Scrooge McDuck and another you are losing towns to rebels because of dying Governors without enough cash to fight back , let alone buy half a particle of dirt. This second phase is the main reason I can't get a single faction. The game gives you about 255 years to conquer all factions but even Alexander the Great couldn't win.SummaryChallenge - 8/10Replayability - 8/10Battles - 6/10Price - Rome Total War - Worth It           Rome Total War Collection - Yes if Previous Fan           Rome Total War Master Collection - Nope           Rome Total War Grand Master Collection - Not even if you are Bill GatesVerdict - Buy

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
PROS:+ huge campaign map+ a LOT of various factions available to play+ fun & tactical gameplay+ interesting units+ town upgrades & logistics+ TONS of cool mods+ ancient times atmosphere+ Barbarian Invasion expansion includedCONS:- a bit outdated graphics- wonky diplomacy system against AI- the rebel armies appear too often- weaker multiplayerComment:I finally bought this game here on Steam so I would have a digital copy of it as my discs are getting really old. This game is worth purchasing because it is a phenomenal RTS game and a must-have part of the Total War series. The graphics have aged but the game still looks decent and let us face it - the game has always been about gameplay first. Multiplayer is fun but the single-player campaign is what this game excels at. A huge map with three roman factions to choose from initially, later each defeated nation is unlocked as playable in the campaign. The gameplay is divided into 3 parts - cities management, sea battles and land battles. The last one is what this game is about and what makes it truly great. All the units, even siege engines, are nicely done and serve a purpose. The fighting is tactical and fair, although sometimes hard. But nothing beats the feeling of  a victory when you are outnumbered 4 to 1, or more! The AI has some problems but that can be forgiven in this case because it does not break the game at all. On top of all this are the mods, the lovely awesome mods. There are so many it would be hard to write all the good ones but MY personal favourites are Europa Babarorum, Lord of the Rings - Total War & Rome Total Realism. Seriously this game is worth your money if you like RTS games so I quite happily recommend it!

content:
Posted: April 22
												Rome Total War is the best in the Total war series and even ranks amoug the top games of all time.  I consider it the second best RTS of all time, only following AOE2. Playing massive battle where you can go head first in frontline action is absolutly mesmorising. Anyone can play Rome Total War but it takes a pro to be good. You need to perfect tactics and have to know the ins and outs of each map. This game stands the test of time beaytifully, If your invading a citadel or recreating Thermopylae you are always having a great time because Rome total War, no mater how many times you have played it, always bring a new scenario to the table, something you didn't expect. I believe Rome Total War will always have a loyal fanbase that will constantly find new and improved tactics. Each map is masterfully constructed with amazing attention to detail, for example you can....-invade towns, cities, and giant citidels-recreate battles of the past on a massive scale-Play multiplayer with friends (my favorite style)-Make a battle of your own-Quick play for a quick and fun battle-the campaign (This is unplayed by many, I have never heard someone say, boy, i could go for some Rome Total War campaign)These styles and many more is what makes Rome Total War so memorible and fun. If your playing with friends or, playing alone Rome Total War is always incredibly entertaining.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Any fan of the total war games will have owned or played this at some point, and played it to death. I caught onto the total war series a little late in my gaming career, yet, they all have the same staying power of each other.Rome: Total War is one of the most iconic in the series and widely regarded as the turning point for the franchise, boosting the already formidable number of titles that were available. In the game you are able to take control of one of the historically correct houses: Julii, Brutii, and Scipi - each as advantages over one another with faction specific attributes. You get to start off with a few generations within the house and begin to build you empire in an attempt to control all 15 other factions. I preferred this to Rome: Total War 2 – which I felt lacked the diplomacy and hierarchy incentives of the first game, it made the experience much more interesting and personal. The game is a great place to start for players new to the franchise, the GFX are a little dated now but you will easily see past it within the first 2 hours as you start to assemble an army. I would recommend trying this out if you’re tentative as it’s quite cheap now and can likely be picked up in a bundle at some point.

content:
Posted: April 22
												Rome Total War is the best in the Total war series and even ranks amoug the top games of all time.  I consider it the second best RTS of all time, only following AOE2. Playing massive battle where you can go head first in frontline action is absolutly mesmorising. Anyone can play Rome Total War but it takes a pro to be good. You need to perfect tactics and have to know the ins and outs of each map. This game stands the test of time beaytifully, If your invading a citadel or recreating Thermopylae you are always having a great time because Rome total War, no mater how many times you have played it, always bring a new scenario to the table, something you didn't expect. I believe Rome Total War will always have a loyal fanbase that will constantly find new and improved tactics. Each map is masterfully constructed with amazing attention to detail, for example you can....-invade towns, cities, and giant citidels-recreate battles of the past on a massive scale-Play multiplayer with friends (my favorite style)-Make a battle of your own-Quick play for a quick and fun battle-the campaign (This is unplayed by many, I have never heard someone say, boy, i could go for some Rome Total War campaign)These styles and many more is what makes Rome Total War so memorible and fun. If your playing with friends or, playing alone Rome Total War is always incredibly entertaining.
