content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Rome: Total War is beginning to show its age, but even 10 years after release it is still one of the best strategy games set in ancient Rome, and is probably the closest one can come to conquering and ruling the known world as a Roman emperor. Large-scale battles, spectacular sieges, trade, diplomacy, assassination - Rome has it all. The greatest, and possibly only, weakness is the dumb AI, which has trouble applying any tactics outside of a head-on assault.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Rome Total War A great game despite it's age.Graphics 4 of 10It's a really old game and the first total war game with 3D units instead of animated 2D sprites so you can't expect much in the way of graphics. and what you expect is what you get.Learning curve (the lower the number the less learning curve there is) 5 of 10The tutorials are good and the game is fairly simple to get into. This game has some learning curve for those who have never played any other RTSes but for those who have played other RTSes before they will have no problem getting into this game's controls.Gameplay (on the battlefield) 7.5 of 10Pros.+Siege battles are very fun and challenging without being too hard.+Land battles are Fun and tactical without being too hard.+The AI is very good for a game of this age and can keep up with human opponents.Cons-some units are a bit over-powered such as elephants.-some units are completely worthless unless under very specific circumstances such as the incendiary pigs that are only effective against elephants and have a tendency to kill more of your own people then the enemy’s that are killed due to the attack.and they do the same thing that a barrage of fire arrows from your archers could do.Overall the land battles are very fun to play and are even better if you can find a human opponent to play with (CA recently migrated this game to steam due to the gamespy shutdown.)Gameplay (Grand campaign) 4.5 of 10Pros. +can be very fun when everything works well in tandem.Cons-Very dated-It is nigh imposable to keep your budget in check when at war.-diplomacy is clunky-auto-resolving battles tends to end with your army losing a battle that anyone could win when controlling the units themselves.Overall the campaign is good at times and really bad at others.Overall 7 of 10.Rome Total War is a game of two qualities; on one hand the battles are great and fun to command, on the other side the campaign is clunky, and not all that great at all. The good does outweigh the bad however. I completely recommend this game as custom and historical battles circumvent the horrid campaign and go to what is great about Rome Total War the combat.

content:
Posted: January 23
												I had played this game before picking it up on Steam and in the end I decided to do it through here as well, as I kinda miss it, I only had the base game, and it was stupidly cheap. As I usually do, I'm gonna start sharing what the game does wrong, then going up from there.First and foremost, one of the worst parts of the game has to be the auto-battle option. You see, you'll be doing tons of big battles here, and if you feel like you don't need to oversee this one, you can just let the AI do it for you. However it seems the auto-battle AI is as brain-dead as Trump. I've lost quite a lot of battles because I had a ton of crap to fight and didn't wanna spend an hour doing them all properly. The last one being over 2k of my troops against 200 rebel peasants. F#CKING PEASANTS. AND MY TROOPS WERE HIGH TIER, WITH SIEGE UNITS AND EVERYTHING. HOW THE F#CK DID THAT HAPPEN!? It will make your playthroughs stupidly long, but I seriously advice you to not use that feature at all.Second is something I'm still not a big fan of. At the start you only have three factions to choose, the three big families of rome (not counting the Senate). However there's a f#ckload of factions, to unlock them you must be the one taking their last area on the map. Why? Why not, for example, certain factions unlocking others at the end of a long game? This way you might unlock a few of them in one game, most likely the ones you don't really want, and will have to restart anew with a faction that's closest to the one you do like, putting yourself through with a faction you don't want. Lastly, I feel like archers are a bit too powerful at times. Sure, heavy troops can tank those arrows and horse units can just sprint to them and whoop their asses, but then we got archers on horses and the whole balance f#cks itself. Elephants are also somewhat powerful since the auto-balance system doesn't seem to understand what the f#ck they do and usually win insane battles.That being said, this is a really cool strategy game that still stands strong after all these years that will give you hours and hours of fun for a really low price.The thing I like the most, strangely enough, is the realism and history stuff on it. It's actually kinda fun to sometimes stop and read all of the stuff the game has to tell you about troops, buildings and such. If you actually don't know much about the roman times, you'll learn a lot in here.The strategy itself is also really cool. It's not one of those "send all of your troops against them blindly" kind of games. The game is surprisingly deep and there's tons of cool tactics you can use to win even the most harsh fights.The amount of factions is also impressive for the time the game came off. There's like f#cking 40 or so, from all of those there HAS to be at least ONE you like. Also, as dumb as it might sound, the dialogue from the captains before the fights are so well written, I can't help but to stop and listen to them constantly. Seriously, they had a blast with those.Honestly, if you want Shogun 2 but you can't affort it, this is a really good alternative. On a sale it costs like 1 or 2€ and it's completely worth it. Though if you do have the money, I'd say give Shogun 2 a try instead.TL;DR Edition: A classic that still stands strong by now. While Shogun 2 feels better, this one is way cheaper. If you enjoy hollywood-speeches, then it's already worth the purchase.

content:
Posted: January 26
												(go to discr_strat to add in factions) My Barbarian invasion story:I started as the Burgundii and decided to become a pirate by building 200 boats and decided to form a horde. I send my King and his sons on the boats and set sail for a life as a pirate. First i raid Denmark then set sail and raided York. Raids the coasts of france, found the Roman Emperor in a costal town on the west coast of france, i then perceed to raid it and thus killing the emperor. I then raid the coast of spain, i then headed  to Morrocco but they decided to send reinforcements to the city i was raiding, therefore decided to go back to the ships and carry on too Carthage. The Romans, clearly not forgeting my regiced decided to send a huge reinforcement of ships and attacked killing the king and his borthers. But all  hope was not lost, by some meraculous chance (probably a glitch due to his two son maturing on board the ship while it was attacked) the king must have sent his 16 year old sons on a ship to escape the battle, and must have got ship recked off the coast of Mauritania and traveled to western Algeria. While travelling through the desert his name must have ment much in the area as hundreds of local mercenairies flocked to his side. He also gained great knowlage of philosophy and his brother converted to Christianity and became deeply interested in theology. After about a decade of travelling they converged on the wooden walled city in the middle of an oasis in the Sahara. The city contained the crown prince of the berbers and wasnt going to give it up easily, and thus he was defeated by the narrowest of margins, but  out of the some respect he let the two princes go so they decided to head east and found a small poor city in modern day Libya. The recent economic crisis had taken hold despite rapid modernisation they decided to leave. The Christian prince decided he wanted too go to the holy land to settle and free from Roman tyranny, his pagan brother agreed and they set sail for Jerusalem. they stopped off at crete which they promptly freed from the Romans and started to modernise a great fleet to get too Jerusalem, however when they set sail again they where intercepted by a roman fleet which won a narrow victory agianst him were he was then killed. Though the philospher princes had with no hair, word must have spread and a new Bergundii warlord, that had prevoiusly parted with the king when the king decided to become a pirate, had heard of the legendry philosphers and their wish, so he and the remnents of the Burgundii army attacked constaninople and used it to cross to Anatolia where they went down a coast route evading roman forces. from a secret path shown too them by a local spy they had managed to besige Jerusalem, they had won as the city wasnt properly gaurded and they managed to settle Jerusalem. After 6 mounths (1 turn) after the conquest of Jerusalem, the warlord had died of the plague and once agian with no heir the royality of the Burgundii had fallen. The end.10/10 Somehow you can create awsome stories (from events and traits) when you form a horde on Barbarian Invasion.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												One of the 10 best PC games of all time; far better than Rome 2 TW overall.   Unit collisions, gameplay, factions, diplomacy, family, historical battles, modding, ... just to name a few.  This game engine was the star of not one, but 2 television shows (Decisive Battles on History Chanel with Matthew Settle, and Time Commanders on BBC from 2003-2005).   An excellent mod for the game is Darthmod 9.01.  There are many others excellent mods.Added 9 months later:Still the best overall TW game, followed by MTW2. If this game were updated with increased family, factions, diplomacy, and maybe most importantly not use that Warscape 2.5 engine (crap collisions no matter how they try to mask it in Sho2 & later games, even tho Sho2 has best use to date of that obsolete from day 1 lousy excuse of an engine), I would pay up to $100 for it. But not for a screwed up "reinvent the wheel" excuse of a game and gameplay like in RTW2.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												So good that to this date mods are still being released for it. A pillar for the Total War series and the best Creative Assembly release for the Roman Era (better than Rome 2 in every way but the graphics). If you get this, like every other good TW title, make sure to try out some mods as they make the game infinitely replayable and will provide you with the best Rome 1 Total War moments. Mods like Rome Total Realism or Europa Barbarorum are two of my favorite. Mods help out in what the game lacks, which is historical accuracy. Some even improve the AI and even the outdated graphics. Unlike the most recent titles with the terrible battle animations, in Rome 1 if a soldier is surrounded by 5 enemy soldiers all of them will stab him untill his hitpoints reach 0 and he dies, instead of playing a battle animation with every single one of them while the others look and wait. Great Classic that aged well and is still enjoyable as hell - 9/10

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												10\10 (Life changing)While my steam play is only about 10 hours, I used to play this game back when you would goto the store to buy a computer game (or the fifth grade). That being said, I've easily put hundreds of hours into this game over the years.This game was the first of the total wars I've played and stands second to maybe the newer versions of total war games. Smooth interactions on the campain and battle maps make navigation and stratgy easy. The A.I. can be easy at times but ramp up the difficulty and you may find yourself in a tricky spot during your campain. The game offers many different factions with a big yet easy to follow diplomacy setting and notifications to allow you to build up your own faction. Today the Mulitplayer is acomplishable but unless you have a freind that plays you probably wont find another player.The steam version is up to date as you would expect and is a great  and cheap way to break anyone into the total war experience without beating an older PC to death with the high demands of shogun 2 (awesome game as well) and Rome 2 (which was dissapointing). RECOMMNEDED.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												My biggest 2 issues with this game:Campaign: Holding large territories is virtually impossible due to unrest, I guess that is historically accurate (even on easy), but counter-intuitive to your objectives.Battles: Unit and camera control are both a disaster. Why they decided against a traditional RTS camera (even though there is an RTS camera option in the game) is beyond me. Moving the mouse to the sides rotates the camera instead of scrolling the map...same goes for the arrow keys. Units themselves are hard to control and rarely do what you tell them to. Want your cavalry to attack a certain squad from behind? Well, first you have manually move them to avoid all other enemies in sight and then they may still attack the wrong enemy. Battles frequently look like masses of pixels trying to get to the enemy, but the game engine doesn't allow that.A good example of how to do it right would be Dawn of War. Here units first engage in ranged combat, but when they are forced into melee they are actively looking for a direct opponent instead of creating 2 big masses of armies that patiently wait until the front line disintegrates. You can micro manage some of that, but honestly, it's really annoying and just lazy in my opinion.Apart from that the game is actually pretty good if you're looking for Grand Strategy and the historic battles you can replay from the menu are fun and challenging, but also give you interesting info about what happened back then.

												The goal of Rome: Total War is to conquer, rule, and manipulate the Roman Empire until you're declared the Imperator of Rome. Rome: Total War is set in a time when the mighty Roman Empire emerged to conquer the known world; when gladiators fought to a bloody death in the Colosseum; and when Hannibal led his invincible army and his war elephants across the Alps. Now you can experience all these legendary moments and more, while building cities and settlements that can grow and develop over time.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												The reason this says I have only played about .3 hours is becuse I have the game as a nonsteam game, so I family shared this version. This game is the greatest game of all time.No joke, unlike its terrible succesor, Total War Rome 2, This game is superior with AI, campaign and battles. You pick a faction in 270 BC and build armies and take over the entire ancient world. The Campaign is spectacular, with good campaign AI and diverse factions. I personally believe that Medieval 2 Total War had the better campaign but thats not the point. The Battles are very good, making you think real time tactics for your army so your enemy doesnt kill you. Wether you like strategy games or not, you buy this game. BUY IT RIGHT NOW (and not Rome 2 cause it sux)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												he game that launch the Total War series towards heights that it could've never dreamed of. This game is a turn-based strategy game where you take command the various factions during the Roman Era as you command, build, govern and attack Rome's enemies.The battle system unlike the system you will see in the modern day versions of the game is really simplistic. Sort of like an almost modern update of Imperial Glory. Now of course, the usual complaint would be "OMG the game is too hard" or "OMG the online players are wrecking me" Luckily the game has an in-depth tutorial plus you have all the time in the world as this game offers various combat both historical and custom made as you polish your skills in battle. And also being a leader of Rome.

												The best Total War game of all time. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												As a newcomer to the Total War series, I must express just how enthralled I am by the gameplay of Rome: Total War. It is an impressive strategy game that lets you live out those dreams of amassing a large army. Now these armies can be massive, carrying at least 1,200 soldiers, and don't even get me started on the reinforcements. However, it's not just a mere 'pick up and play' sort of game. This is a game that requires thinking, as a turnbased strategy game. You start off with a faction in the imperial campaign, where you are then given a large map of Europe that is populated with other factions of that time, such as the Greek, Egyptians, Gauls, Spanish, and many more. It is up to you to conquer Europe and extinquish all other factions from the competition. You can also choose to become allies with a few of these factions, if you want. The diplomacy feature in this game provides heaps of options, from trade rights with other factions, to extortion, or you can tell other factions to attack your rivals.Each faction has its own economy, but I won't get into that. Admittedly, I'm not very good at this part. This requires constructing certain buildings to improve income, such as shrines to Jupiter or crops. You can choose to have each settlement have its own taxation. But set it too low, and your citizens may revolt and start an uprising. This is a game that requires lots of patience, and your experience should not be rushed. But there is no joy greater than conquering that final Spanish settlement, sending hundreds of infantry troops to slaughter them, while your archers lie back, and bring fire to the various buildings until finally, you have wiped their existence from the face of the Earth.Overall, Rome: Total War is a thrilling experience that you'll find yourself investing many many hours in. Oh, did I also mention that you can play historical battles that took place in real life? Or if that sounds too boring, you can create your own custom matches.

												This game started my passion for Total War games, and remains my favorite.  My logged hours does no justice to the actual time I've spent on this game. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												One of my favorite Total War games. I used to play this all of the time, back when it was on CD. It provides a ton situations to deal with: politics, diplomacy, family, war, financing, and strategy. Your empire's development is slow to start, but soon after you empire expands diplomacy and senate appeasing is important. Then you have to worry about your new neighbors to the north who also want your land. However, the Senate wants another territory on the opposite side of the empire to be taken. So you have to balance your troops, as you can only afford so much. While that is going on your citizens are upset at the tax rate and need to be subdued.This game is complex and a great starting game for the Total War series. As it has many ways to play and I still to this day can be entertained, even with the graphics not being as shiny as Rome: Total War 2.

												It' is now worth saying no game is perfect, I will not call  this game perfect. but it is, perhaps, one of the greater gaming expirences. If you overlook the (now) outdated graphics, there is great gameplay, and the start of one of the most succesfull RTS (Real Tme Strategy) series ever. But enough positivity, lets look at what took this game down.the graphics are sub-par and the models only have spikes as feet on anything but the highest graphic setting. The sound is compresses and the AI is braindead approximatley 60% of the time, leaving little room for grand strategy. The AI on campign denies fair diplomecy for no reason and commences wars for no reason. this game is fantastic but those are the three biggest flaws. Not to mention the crippiling bugs!7/10

This game is for you !- Pretty good graphism for his era, - The Total War serie is definitely one of the bests strategic games serie,- You can choose betwin a lot of civilizations,- Realistic animations of fights and death,- The interface is really ergonomic,- Economic and social systems easy to understand,- There is not so much politic,- The AI have a good balance,- The campaign is really funny to play,- The map is big,- Fight maps are realistics,- There is some anecdotes about real History moments.You to try this game !

content:
Posted: March 22
												It' is now worth saying no game is perfect, I will not call  this game perfect. but it is, perhaps, one of the greater gaming expirences. If you overlook the (now) outdated graphics, there is great gameplay, and the start of one of the most succesfull RTS (Real Tme Strategy) series ever. But enough positivity, lets look at what took this game down.the graphics are sub-par and the models only have spikes as feet on anything but the highest graphic setting. The sound is compresses and the AI is braindead approximatley 60% of the time, leaving little room for grand strategy. The AI on campign denies fair diplomecy for no reason and commences wars for no reason. this game is fantastic but those are the three biggest flaws. Not to mention the crippiling bugs!7/10

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												This is the best Total War in the franchise even better than Total War: Rome II. There's just so something awesome bout these factions that really make you feel you are the one who is controling everything and dominating all. The armies itself are very unique giving each faction their own individual units that make the game feel so much more refreshing when you're wanting to play another campaign because you have the chance to experience the different units.The gamplay itself is very strategic where you see your men in their formations and positions ready to attack or defend. You may be outnumbered but if you stick to formations, strategic planning you can win which I very like that you need to use your brain to win.The game has the best soundtrack in any Total war game, it fits the battles perfectly and makes it epic too. The Generals speech are very cool to hear aswel while you hear your soldiers cheering. Finally the utscenes are really entertaining to watch as well just seeing if your spy or assassn failed/succeeded the mission. Now when I say this game is better than Rome 2 I don't mean it but I do. Rome 2 has probably the most stupidest AI ever and the most content removed from. I won't go into detail because I am not reviewing the game (Also I don't have it on steam).

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												I love this game. That said, the tendency to crash before or after(which is much worse) battles, is fairly annoying. Wuhu! I just spectacularly annihilated an army, killing the king, taking the Capitol, winning the game...CRASH! At least when it has the decency to do it on the loading screen pre-battle you don't want to smash your computer. Would be nice to play all factions, but i hear there's a way to do that. Overall I like Seleucia or the Scipii best, Brutii next. Gauls have good shrines, too. If Seleucia could only make the Nike & Artemis shrines as well as their Hephaestus 1 they'd be invincible. Plus, I  LOVE all the cheats; never play without the money cheat or the fog 1. Making all the buildings at once also cuts down on excrutiating waiting for stuff to be built, wish I could get the troop cheats besides oliphaunt to work.(though the oliphaunts are cool) Yes , I'm a lazy control freak who'd play every game in god mode if possible, so I like as many cheats as I can get. I wish I could control all factions like on Medieval TW. Really, it's less like playing as king of an empire as the benevolent god that makes his chosen people totally wealthy & OP. My subjects are happy because they have low taxes & all the buildings in their city instantly built.(most of my governers have"the builder" in their name.) I don't feel even remotely bad for cheating because the game does it all the time. I've had enemy cites down to 25/30% loyalty & they wouldn't rebel: it jumps to 100 randomly(with 4 high lvl spies & a smashed temple in it,1unit). Meanwhile, your citii rebel at 70%, with a full garrison. My other favorite thing in the game is the assassinations. Nothing beats winning the game by whacking the enemy heirs & king. Plus it's cool getting"the killer" after your king's name. I've whacked many whole factions out of existence without ever going to war, with trade treaties the whole time. One thing I dislike about Barbarian Invasion is I can't use my sleazy go-to tactic of buying off the other 1/2 of the Empire's generals/troops/cities. "ooo a 5-star general w/ a full stack...sure would be fun to make him turn on his own cities & butcher the inhabitants thereof." I once bought Corinth off Macedonia as the Brutii to get the Zeus shrine. The senate wasn't pleased cuz it wasn't on their orders, but the people loved me. I bought a Gaul gen when I was Brutii, he sat in the capitol getting ancilliaries 'til he was 50 & I had an army for him, he then stomped all of Greece, took Halicarnassus, Rhodes, then Crete & finally Messina. He was 6 star, 9 when fighting in any situation. He became Praetor. I made him heir because he earned it, not to mention being way better than any of the family. Only the faction leader was his equivalent, but he'd fought as many battles & was Pontifex Maximus. What's the game like without all the cheats? Painfully slow & unplayable by my standards. Bankrupt & running a deficit within a couple of years, getting your butt whupped by ai that doesn't seem to be have a cashflow problem, they just contiunously build their cities & have huge army stacks everywhere.Mind you , I play on easy; I can't imagine what they think hard is. I've found many game devs equate easy with impossible. I think it means impossible to lose.(like when cheating heavily) I'm powerless enough in real life, when gaming, at least against ai, I want to be omnipotent. Losing's no fun, & I find it deeply satisfying to have no casualties in a battle where I annihilate the other army. I just want to crush my enemies, see them driven before me ,& hear the lamentation of the women, beacause that's what's best.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												For an old game, it's pretty well made and executed. Definitely worth 10 bucks.I used to watch a lot of Rome Total War let's plays and I got pretty excited when I was able to download this from steam. The game starts you out playing as one of the three Roman factions, all of their intros distinct and unique. As I started the campaign I had a mixed sense of awe and fear. My first playthrough as the Brutii I enjoyed ravaging the cities of Macedon, Thrace and Greece. I did play on easy but there were some battles along the way that had suprised me and kept me emotionally invested in my campaign forth to the east. I remember countering the Phalanx heavy armies of Greece, Thrace, and Macedon, with skirmishers, artillery and archers whittling them down as they marched toward me. The same tactic worked for every battle with me always taking the hill. However I remember being annihilated by being caught in-between reinforcements and the main Macedonian army. I won, I lost, and I would never make the same mistake again.After deciding to raise the stakes (Hard/Hard) and playing as a much less civilized faction (Germania) I found myself squished in-between the armies of Gaul, Britannia, and Dacia. I began my campaign reuniting the german people and invading what is now France and Britain and then proceeding into the territory that is known today as Austria. My empire was huge, to the west were the Spanish and to the east were the Scythians, and to the south were the Romans. With the Spanish and the Scythians at peace with me and Dacia all but scattered across the lands, I began my march into the Alps and into Rome itself.For the Romans, it seemed too late, battle after battle I left their Hestati and Principe armies defeated and scattered, their war machines burnt to the ground and their cities pillaged and burned. They could not stop the hordes of horsemen nor the cries of the beserkers, Rome was crumbling. However, I faced as much more devastating enemy as I conquered their cities, holding them. There were constant rebellions and with the Romans building navies and giant army stacks at sea (and then landing in my territory) I had a rough time with them. When the Romans took a city, I couldn't take it back, simply because their walls were too strong to hold at siege. The Julii and the Scipii were battling the Numidians and the Carthaginians to the south, and then using the wealth from those campaigns to take back their homes. The Brutii were marching entire armies of Urban Cohorts, Legionaries, and the Praetorian Guard at my doorstep. Soon, my economy collapsed and I had begun to fear the threat of being overrun. I could take Rome, but could I hold it? After countless battles I eliminated the Julii and both the Brutii and Scipii were on the run. My armies all had silver/gold chevrons weapons and armor (upgrades) after such battles, so I was able to defeat many of their experienced warriors.Then I decided to download Darthmod for Rome....Every battle against the Romans was different than before and it had me running scared. I fought smaller army stacks and although I would outnumber them my men would leave the battle completely depleted. I couldn't auto-resolve otherwise I would end up losing and with the Egyptians, Pontus, Thracians, and the Spanish barbarians marching toward my gates I had one hell of a time. All in all, I had more fun than any other game I've played. The mods bring me back, and the battles are fantastic. Rome: Total War is certainly worth the money.

Rome 2 has probably the most stupidest AI ever and the most content removed from. I won't go into detail because I am not reviewing the game (Also I don't have it on steam).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I played this game for years, and I remember the day I bought this game in a shop, and the first battles (battle at Carrhae, damn Horse archers!) and campaigns (Brutti and Julii, and that moment you unlocked more factions !!). It was really magical. Sadly the disk version is not working in windows 10, and on my older computer it really lags, so I bought it again, but now on steam, for a discount of 50%. On the plus side with Barbarian invasion.This is, in my opinion, the best total war game. Some may say it is not really historical, as you have factions like "the Gauls" and "Germania", while in reality they were countless tribes. True, but I never minded it. I always made my own stories. And that is the magic I think. You should create your own stories, like a king that unites the Dacian tribes and invades Greece, etc. You shouldn't play this game just for gameplay. No. Because you want to create your own stories and love the era. Everything is great, well, almost everything then. The campaign is fun, the battles are. You want to play as every faction, try everything out, etc. However, the Romans ofcourse are the best. You have the Senate, missions for them etc. Eventually you will get a pop up saying that the people want you to invade Rome and be their leader, so you can have a civil war! The few downsides are maybe the squalor problem, which will be rampant in the mid to late game, and sometimes breaks the fun, or the sporadic fps killers on modern computers. But I think they are neglectable. There are also tons of mods, but I have never tried one, I like the vanilla version.Great game, it is cheap nowadays (especcially during steam sales), plus you get Barbarian invasion, which moves the whole atmosphere to the end of the Roman Empire, and with religion, tribe migrations, etc. although I haven't tried it yet. STOP SCROLLING THROUGH THE REVIEWS, AND BUY IT ALREADY!!!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												One of the best games of all time, and definitely the best RTS of all time. The graphics and physics engines have become a little dated (2004-based) but if you enjoy the time period or game genre Rome: Total War is a must-play. You can choose between many different factions, each with their own unique play style and units, and recreate history or forge your own path. You can use diplomats, assassins and spies, fleets and massive armies.Due to the (relative) simplicity of the coding there are mods aplenty from total conversions (think Lord of the Rings) to complete historical-accuracy rehauls, making Rome that much more replayable and unique.

number of helpful: 25 of 53 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												If you bought this to play multiplayer, ignore my not recommended and buy it immediately, as there is no other option for reliable online multiplayer at this point.If you're looking to play the singleplayer, DON'T get this version. Buy it on disc from a retailer or online, or torrent it. Why do you ask? In returning multiplayer to this game with steamworks, which I applaud CA for doing, they completely destroyed the performance of the game somehow. No clue how they manage to mess up something so simple, but I have about 100% worse performance with the steam version of the game compared to the older, gamespy version. Another thing is that 99% of mods aren't compatible with steam Rome Total War so you're going to have trouble playing your favourite overhauls with this. Serious FPS trouble with a i7 2600k and GTX 960 on MEDIUM settings, i'm talking drops to 10 FPS in not even remotely huge battles. Unacceptable. I get a almost smooth 60 in similar conditions on my disc copy.Pros - Multiplayer is returnedCons -Absolutely terrible performance for most people after the patchIncompatibility with most mods.

content:
Posted: January 13
												Developed by The Creative Assembly, Rome: Total War is a revolutionary classical title in the best-selling Total War series that carries players into the midst of ancient history's most intense conflicts. Rome: Total War features groundbreaking technology [For it's time]  that brings the epic, cinematic battles of the Roman era to life with graphics and gameplay beyond anything previously seen in a PC game, at that time. Players will be transported to the battlefields of ancient history's greatest conflicts and control mighty armies. Up to 10,000 fully polygonal, highly detailed, motion-captured warriors can appear on the screen at once. They control vast armies led by history's most legendary generals including Julius Caesar and Hannibal, and must use a combination of brains and brawn to successfully conquer the Roman Empire.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												I played this game for about 80 hours shortly after it came out (I don't know, 10 years ago or something). It was fun at the time, and can be fun still. It took a little tweaking to get it to run under Steam. Have to set the -ne option so the game runs in windowed mode in order to go into the video settings and set the correct resolution (otherwise it just quits right after starting up). That problem solved, I jumped in at 1920x1200 and it ran fine. But, I am reminded of the user interface which I did not like last time I played it. The graphics have also aged poorly after so many years. I recall at the time, and again just today when I put another hour into the game, that the UI is distracting, making it take about twice as long to get things done as I would prefer (versus a competing game like Civilization IV, at the time, which is much smoother to handle). Overall, I can't recommend this game today to anyone but a fan of the series. There are better strategy choices. Not least of which is Rome II, which is more updated than this old one.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												Oh wow.  Performance is really bad.  I mean BAD.  My main machine has a FX8320 @ 4.6GHz and an overclocked HD7850.  Can't run the game at more than 30fps no matter what settings I lower or turn off.  Tried it on a secondary machine with a stock Phenom 9650 and a R7 260X and the same deal.  I clearly remember being able to play this game a little after it came out with an Opteron 165 and a X1950XT at full settings with no fps problems.  At first I imagined it was a driver issue, but then I decided to dig out my old original RTW CDs, and after jumping several hoops to get it installed, sure enough, I was able to play the game at max settings with my fps numbers in the high 50s on average.  WUT?Whatever.  I got it on sale and for convenience (my old CDs are scratched already).  As it is the game is painful to play.  I then read the negative Steam reviews after the fact.  I highly recommend the game, just not this version.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												A bit dated now, but it still has the best feel of all the total war games due mainly to the music and sound. The epic feel of defending against a siege attack, rushing your tired men to and from weak points, again the music brings real tension in the battles, elation in victory and almost tears when your once certain victory is snatched from you in the last minutes. Its one of those games that will give you great memories. You will actually feel fear when you see a full stack of gaullish celts appear from a mountain pass on the main map, not knowing what there intentions are and hoping they dont come your way. This game also enables you to play the excellent Europa Barborum mod for the history pedants.

												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												This is a bad game that found itself with a good reputation. The epic 3D battles were so stunning that critics were willing to ignore some major flaws.To call the AI stupid is an insult to the very concept of stupidity. It fights battles well enough, but simply cannot handle the campaign map, which means it rarely has any troops to bring to the battle. Even heavy doses of cheating cant help this guy. Wheatly would be better.Diplomacy is an incredible pain in the neck. You cannot just summon a rival to a meeting; you must train a Diplomant, have him physically walk across the map; and then suggest a trade, which the AI will disagree to.There is only one starting faction: Rome. To play as anyone else you must complete the campaign... which grows boring long before your even close to done.If your looking to get into Total War (which is a very good idea) I would reccomomend Shogun 2, Attila, or Warhammer. If you want to see what the series is all about without breaking the bank, grab the original Shogun. It utilizes a Risk style map that makes life for the AI much, much better.Whatever you choose, I hope you enjoy.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Only because for some reason it's ridiculously unstable, I got 100 turns into a campaign and it seems to CTD no matter how many saves I go back. It's still infinitely better than anything CA has released since medieval 2, and for a fraction of the priceCombat in this game is fast paced and fun, with many varied units and every faction having a unique feel. The battle AI is what you'd expect from a 10 year old game - having said that, it's better than many new entries in terms of self preservation and repositioning. The campaign takes some understanding of its intricacies (particularly cultural unrest and squalor), but once understood becomes easily manageable, and allows you to better array and deploy forces as you see fitOnce you beat the game (which can take a few days) you'll also have access to almost all of the other factions in the game (without a £3 entry fee, unlike more recent releases) which provides tonnes of replay valueGet this game, but maybe not on steam - my hard copy from 10 years ago works fine and doesn't corrupt my saves, so I can only assume it's a problem with the steam release

number of helpful: 20 of 65 people (31%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												You may be wondering I have not recomendded total war.  Well the reason for that is quite simple.  If i had just recomended it, then my review would have been lost among a sea of other reviews that also recomend it.  Hopefully someone somewhere will actually see this because its in a much smaller pool.  Anyway Rome total war is an excellent game, tatics while rather straightforward most of the time are realistic and you need to have a basic understanding of strategy to beat the AI on anything above easy.  Every faction has different unit compositions to use so your tatics will have to change on subsequent playthroughs.  Basically Rome Total war has a stunning amount of depth and historical accuracy put into it.  While the graphics don't hold up a decade later, the gameplay is superior to even the sequel Rome TW 2 which came out several months ago.  This game is worth the full price even today, and if your looking to get into total war, or getting your friends into total war, this is a great starting point or gift respectively.  To give you some basic tatics, rome's usual goal is to when not facing phalanxes just mash your infantry into the enemy, as your infantry are essentially the greatest in the world.  While there is more to it then that namely using light infantry to hold your flanks whilst heavy infantry splits the enemy down the center, using your cavaly to take out enemy seige weapons or to flank a phalanx, thats all there is to it.  When playing as greece your goal is to not get flanked, as you have the most powerful phalanxes in the world and will almost never lose if you don't get flanked.  Carthages goal is to use elephants and support cavalry to literaly blow holes in the enemy line and crush enemy morale, whilst your infantry pin the enemies center or flanks in place, depending on the lay of the land.  If your parthia you want to make the enemy chase you and use hit and run tactics as you have the best cavalry in the world, and the greatest horse archers to ever live.  and so on.  Basically buy this ♥♥♥♥ing game.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												When I first bought this when it was first released (back in them ol' pre-Steam days), I was ultimately underwhelmed by it. Then I played it again, and grew to like it more. I lost the CD's, but found it on Steam and got it to try playing it again. After a while, I uninstalled it. Now, at least twice in the past few years, I've thought about the game, reinstalled it, played it for a day or two, then uninstalled it again. Why? Because, really, in the end, I'm underwhelmed.RTW CAN be a fun game. I've done multiplayer against friends, and enjoyed it immensely. I like the various units available. With the Roman factions, I like playing the various quests to win approval in the Senate and among the populace. I wouldn't call it the worst game in existence.So why, then, am I still underwhelmed?First, there are some serious problems with this game's battle mechanics. You will have to literally micromanage your units, and like 1-year old children you won't be able to leave them alone for a while, because if you do they will do amazingly stupid things. For example, I had a cavalry unit chase after some routing archers, went to another spot of the battlefield, then when I went back to the cavalry unit, I saw they had decided it would be an awesome idea to charge headlong into a line of spears, and were suffering tremendous casualties. This doesn't even cover that sometimes you could give individual units specific orders, and they'll just ignore you. Then there are some SERIOUS pathfinding issues. Units will take the most random routes to go from point A to point B, even when there shouldn't be an issue. The biggest example of this I can think of was one time when I was besieging a city, and was charging my men (who were not routing) down the main road in the city - apparently, "go charge at the enemy right in front of you" translated into "turn around and head back outside of the city."Second, the campaign map part of the game will be annoying. Diplomacy is virtually USELESS. You could set up alliances with all your neighbors, get trade deals, and generally be peaceful...and then suddenly, for absolutely NO DISCERNABLE REASON, all your neighbors will, one by one, declare war on you. OK, fine, this game is called Total WAR, maybe that can be forgiven. However, none of your opponents will EVER accept a peace deal, even if you've destroyed all their armies in several embarrassing battles, and have taken all their cities except their capitol. You could offer them the best peace deal ever that would ensure their survival, and they would still say, "Nope! Fight to the end!" On top of this, naval battles are just annoying: while they automatically auto-resolve all naval battles, they rarely involve the complete destruction of one side. You could have a fleet of 300 sailors up against a fleet of 13 sailors, and it would still end with the enemy getting away somehow. Aside from blockading fleets, I end up just not caring about navy battles.There are also some issues and bugs that I've noticed in the Steam version of RTW that I didn't see in the original RTW or its expansion. One of the biggest issues is that reinforcements seem to ALWAYS be delayed. Originally it was sporadic enough that it helped make the battles random and unpredictable...now, I no longer expect the reinforcements to come, because the minute I get into battle I get a notification that the reinforcements - either for me or the enemy - have been delayed.In the end, RTW is just not an enjoyable entry into the TW series. After a certain point of wondering why a one-city nation decided it would be wise to launch an attack against my empire, or after the fifth time I've suffered casualties because my men are wandering around the battlefield like wet hens and ignoring what I told them to do, I lose all interest in playing it, and uninstall it. If you want to play a Total War game, I would go look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 8 of 59 people (14%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Total war is a cross between Turn Based Strategy and Real Time Strategy genres, sadly it fails at both. The fights are bland and unless you really enjoy spending 45 minutes of mind numbing unit micromanagement for each battle you'll just let the AI auto resolve conflicts. All you are left with is a mediocre turn based campaign map with military centric building like which barely rivals browser based RTS MMOs (The mechanics are really that simplistic). I've only put in a few hours on this game because honestly I don't see the point. From the very start I had problems with the game, glitchy problems. The tutorial cannot be saved; if you can't sit down and play it for 1 hour straight just forget about the tutorial unless you want to leave the game running in the taskbar while you are away. Then, when I finally got the time to play it for one hour straight, the camera glitched and kept panning to the lower right corner of the map. Since I couldn't save the tutorial I had to quit and start it all over AGAIN for the third time. So I'm through the tutorial, now what? Time to conquer the known ancient world for the glory of Rome! Woot! Three battles later and my mind is changed, this is just boring and pointless. Every battle seems to be pretty much the same, you set up units and let the killing commence. Unit collision never seems to work and in R:TW it means your units behave like daft plebeians; trying to get them all through a gate, ha, half of them always split off and the rest of the time what? Do you really enjoy watching 1000 virtual units fail at each incessantly until the other unit's demise? How about friendly fire? Good stuff right? Your archers mowing down your own army because you forgot to click each archer 'card' and tell them to stop it! How about a real cool zoomed in shot with arrows flying into the camera, cool right?! It is cool the first couple of times but the *cool* factor wears off real quick and you are left struggling to control 1k units who are completely lost without your incessant management. The main map is really no better, it's even more focused on military then your run of the mill RTS. I was really hoping for something more akin to Civilization in depth where you actually gather multiple resources and manage your production but here all that seems to matter is hording gold through exorbitant taxes. This way you build more boring buildings that your citizens need to be happy so you can train more boring armies so you can fight more boring battles at the Senate's behest. Are you bored yet? I think the original title for this game must have been "Rome: Realistic Battle Simulator" but when first screened to an audience the reception was lukewarm so they changed it to something sexier. TLDR, Unless you really enjoy overly simplistic empire management where every RTS battle is 30 minutes or more of the exact same assault plan I recommend you pass on this glorified combat simulator.

The graphiсs and engine are awful, there is no possibility to play as Sparta (why, CA, why?) and instead of that there are 4(!) same factions called Romans. In addition, there are no actual battles, depleted units are not auto-recovering, and for diplomacy you need to hire tons of characters instead of simply doing it through the special menu.There is no balance in war system. As in ROME 2: TOTAL WAR you can choose any faction and be sure that you going to be able to handle opponent, so that requires some skill and thinking, but to win in R1  you simply need to counter opponent with supreme troops…so no tactics here. In addition, Rome is too overpowered and can destroy almost any army in the easy way.Multiplayer is full of weird kids kicking everybody for not-knowing some 3-letter word (don’t remember it), the other guys with CAPS names are ignorant by putting passwords on their games. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												This game is one of the best grand strategy games ever made. While light on diplomacy, this game focuses heavily on the latter two words of the title: Total War.Starting out in 270 BC, you take the helm of one of the patrician families of Rome: the Julii, the Scipii, or the Brutii. While functionally the same, each one has you expanding the empire in a different direction, against different enemies. You must serve the Senate and People of Rome (the SPQR) during your campaigns if you are ever to realise your true final goal: domination of the other Roman families, and the siezure of Rome itself. After completing a campaign as one of the families of Rome, you unlock several new factions to play as, each with their own unique units, religious buildings, locations and much more.The Good:+Turn-based campaign map and real time battles keep the tempo just right. You'll never get bored or be bombarded with too much action.+Very diverse factions, but the Romans typically are the best to start with, due to their favorable situation. More veteran players will like the other factions for their increased challenge.+Challenging campaign that forces you to think about what you are doing, and hopefully not make decisions you'll regret.+Graphics have aged well for a decade old game, and it runs very well on modern systems. Only very underpowered machines will struggle with this game.+Music is intense and epic, and gives the battles a sense of awe when they are large enough.+Battles are fun and can be very challenging. Don't be surprised if the AI outsmarts you sometimes!The Bad:-AI is not always very good. It does not handle sieges very well, and naval warfare is usually trivial as they rarely keep sizeable fleets. Also, weak factions will attack you (often the most powerful faction in the game) for seemingly no reason, and enemies on the brink of destruction will make outrageous demands to you, while your armies are at their doorstep.-Diplomacy is very limited. You can make very limited demands and offers, make alliances and trade rights, but that's about it.-Feed back from the game's building and condition descriptions are very poor, giving the player almost no feed back.The Iffy Stuff (stuff that some people will like, others won't):=The game is VERY long. Even a short campaign will run you a few hours, and you'll need to set aside a few days to do a long one. However, this means this cheap game will provide TONS of entertainment.=The game is quite old, so some will scorn its simplicity, but others will like it.Conclusion:Rome: Total War is still one of the games that truly defines strategy, and its impact is still being felt today. A must buy for strategy enthusiasts and new comers alike.

Posted: February 7, 2014
												I just got done writing a review for TW: Rome 2 and realised my whole review could've been summed into the words "Go play Rome 1 instead."This game, where to even begin? I played an ungodly amount of this game back in the day and when I returned to it, it still felt brilliant as ever. Get some mods off TW: Centre and this game feels fresh and exciting every single time you play it. The graphics look a bit block up close but you'll be at a bird's eye view most of the time so it's of no matter. The unit differences are great. The intra and interfactional politics are ever relevant and fun to play with. The political system allows amazing freedom and flexibility in your diplomatic relations. The deployment of troops makes sense. The strength of weapons and missles make sense. The AI doesn't ever feel overpowered. Seriously, get this game and get a mod like Total Realism.For 10$ you will not get a better RTS game out there honestly. If you need a number, this game gets a 10/10, 5 stars, 100% whatever just do yourself a favour and get this. If TW: Rome 2 left a bad taste in your mouth, this game will fix it by causing endless ♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												Rome: Total War is what its title advertises, the Roman Empire (and the other factions that existed during that period) and the vast, complex and often overwhelming task of leading your chosen faction to greatness. The game is a unique blend of turn-based strategy and real time tactics that Creative Assembly has turned into an ever flourishing series that has earned its praise many times over.You control everything from what buildings to construct in your cities, to which factions you want to conduct business with. That's the turn-based part. Where the "real time tactics" come in is when you fight a battle, commanding your units in real time, as you might have guessed.As far as combat is concerned, it's solid to say the least. You have a great amount of control over your units, even being able to tell them where to move siege towers. However, there are, of course, flaws. It's always frustrating to have your soldiers attack enemies that you didn't send them after, especially when those enemies just happen to be the very thing that can chop your precious soldiers to bits.The diplomacy also suffers a bit, since the AI tends to reject even the most reasonable offers, no matter how much they would profit from them, unless you have a diplomat with a high influence stat, which is gained through successful negotiations. This creates a vicious cycle of useless diplomats, leaving you to solve all matters with the sword, rather than the pen.Over all, this game, however old, is still a gem and well worth your time.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												i had two problems running this game on windows 8.1 64 bit (first: game doesn't launch, only a black screen and then returns to desktop; second: problem "Failed to find Steam"). I finally managed to resolve both, so in case some of you have the same problems, here i post the solutions. I tried many solutions i found on internet:-copied the Steam.dll file from C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam-deleted the ClientRegistry.blob file from C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam (Make sure you are not logged on Steam when doing this).-tried every possible compatibility mode, but not working-tried disabling steam community in game from game properties on steam-tried the solution down here.     1: Right-click on "Computer" (in XP it was called "My Computer") and click on Properties.    2: in Vista / 7, on the left click on "Advanced System Settings". On XP, Google search for how to change your system path, because I can't quite remember where things were in XP.    3: In the Advanced tab, you'll see a button for "Environment Variables". Click it.    4: In the upper section of that new window, you should see something like "User Variables for [your username]". Scroll through to find the one called "PATH".    5: Highlight the entry for "PATH" and click "Edit...".    6: You'll get a too-small text box that has a field on the top for "Variable Name" and a field under it for "Variable Value". Put your cursor into the "Variable Value" field and hit the [End] key so you know you're not inserting text in the middle of another entry. If you push the right arrow key it should not scroll.    7: Add a semicolon [;] to separate your new entry from the others. This is the key to the right of the 'L' key, without      pressing Shift. Correct -> ; Incorrect -> :    8: Paste in the path to Steam, which for me on a default-install Windows 7 64 system is: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam    9: Press OK, and re-launch Steam so that it gets the new environment variables. (It might work without re-launching, but hey why not.)    10: Run the game normally!-finally, i changed the default setting for the use of integrated or dedicated video card, to integrated (mine is Intel HD4000).After all this passages and a system reboot, now the game starts. I don't know exactly if only one or more together of the above solutions was the key, but i know that if you do all of that, the game will start. Try one after another.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												It's the 5th turn in a row that a full stack of Egyptian troops has besieged me in North Africa. After 4 successive sieges without being able to retrain a single unit, the garrison is looking a little f*****. The battle begins, in true defensive siege fashion, every unit is on a chokepoint just next to the centre, i skip the part where the enemy ai knocks down my walls and spends 10mins getting his troops in the city. The panicky advisor screams 'The Walls are down!' ...jeez, calm down mate, it's not over yet. A couple thousand infantry and just under 100 chariots (god, you learn to hate those things) come barreling down the main 'road' towards my town centre, 5mins of carefully stacking my units just right pay off here, most of the chariots bounce off my block of 500 or so legionaries, but, wtf is this!?!?! there is one unit just sat on my town square, they oblige my worst fear and abruptly charge into my neatly packed lines, facing the other direction. What unfolds is a tense fight to the death where i am powerless to help my troops as they are mown down by the chariots, followed closely by infanty, a tense meat grinder, both armies simply melting away in moments...utntil one heroic legionary standard bearer decides to stab the enemy commander in the face, despite hiom being on a chariot. This superhuman feat results in a mass rout...my infantry is too tired to consider a pursuit. I end the battle. The world map loads up, 5 armies down, 8 more to go. Declaring war of Egypt was a terrible idea... (This hasn't beein much of a review, but it simply shows the beautiful anecdotal content this game creates, despite being made in 2004, it still easily holds up to modern gamin, i considered it a benchmark for Rome 2, and found Rome 2 to be lacking...again, proving that this game was insanely ahead of it's time. Would utterly reccommend, one campaign will easily sustain you for 50-100 hours. Enjoy!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												  I was never a strategy gamer.  I always played Call of Duty, Medal of Honor, God of War, and so on and was reluctant to ever play a strategy game.  The few games that I did play which were strategy were Halo Wars and Endwar and both were not my cup of tea.  The execution and view of them were not of my taste.  It was games like this that deterred me from the strategy genre for many years, until my sophomore year of high school.  I was watching a History video in class about Spartacus' rebellion and recognized footage used in the documentary that was obviously lifted from a game.  I knew for some reason that it had to be Rome: Total War.  I don't know what it was, but I just felt the impetus to buy it.  As luck would have it, it was on sale for a dollar on Steam (with Alexander included).  I came into it thinking it would just offer the same as any other strategy game.  Was I ever wrong.   I have an exceptional ability to tell whether a game is good or not and my misjudgement of Rome was rather monumental.  Unlike many strategy games which are either turn based or real time, Rome: Total War was a mixture of both. There is a campagin map which is turn based-driven where the player can move armies, spies, assassins, diplomats, and ships.  There are a number of cities which are capitals to regions that the player can come to control by conquering the city.  There is a little depth with the utilization of resources for income for the faction the player controls.  Players can also spy on other factions' settlements, take part in diplomacy with either leaders or other diplomats, assassinate individuals, or blockade ports to cities.  The campaign map is far from static between turns.     Nevertheless, the charm of Rome is not the campaign map but the battle map.  This is by far the best part of any total war game for me.  I am glad that I played Rome: Total War before any other strategy game because I would have missed out on the dynamic battles which the player get to partake in.  There are basically three flavors of battle:  siege, field, and ambush.  Battles range from besieging cities to fighting in other locals on the campaign map.  If an army is position in a forest, it has the ability to ambush an army.  This is a game changer for it could result in a force of fewer soldiers to defeat a whole legion of the Roman Empire.  The normal battles in the diverse terrains of Rome: Total War are a spectacle to be witnesses.  The player has the ability to either decimate an enemy army or survive the onslaught and exxecute a brilliant last stand.  Fans of ancient warfare and 300 will most definitely enjoy Rome in this regard.  Sieges offer a different style of play.  Siege operate both on the campaign and battle maps.  The player can create multiple siege weapons and assault the city he or she besieges after blockading the city for a number of turns.  Having units scaling the walls of a city or busting through a gate is satisfying.  The most enjoyable part of battles (and from one source I read it seems to be a valid claim) is when two battle lines collide.  The player feels the impact and the game is made just that much better for witnessing such a spectacle.   As with any game there are a few weak points.  For example, naval battles are nonexistent and the player can only approach each naval confrontation with a auto-resolve action.  It really takes away from the game.  Also, the game is not historically accurate to any extent.  Various historical events, save for the Marian reforms and various natural disasters, have no real effect on gameplay.  Also, the AI of other factions is not the greatest.  You'll partake in many battles where you'll be wondering if the AI was really trying or not.  Also, there is the issue that two factions, the Britons and Egyptians, are just overpowering and end up conquering half of the map by mid-game.  It does provide a challenge but it is really annoyting when they eliminate most other factions before you get to meet them; i. e. Parthia.  As a matter of fact, the only time I got to fight the Parthians was when I was playing as the Seleucids.  Another big failing of the game is the monopoly on unit advancement and power that Roman Factions have.  There are basically four Roman factions.  This means that no matter how you play the game, by the latest turns, the whole world will be ruled by Romans.  Again, this takes away the ability of the player to fight a diverse multitude of enemy types.  Exacerbating the issue is the Marian reforms effect on the Roman faction.  It basically turns all of the units into damage sponges.  This would have been okay if other factions were able to advance in such a faction but that isn't the case.  The most sad case is Gaul.  Gaul can get most of its highest level units before the Marian reforms take place.  However, that is only because it has fewer unit choices than the Roman, Carthage, and Seleucid factions.  I understand that it may have been made this way to bolster faction diversity but nevertheless it breaks gameplay for Gaul.  Now with all these problems considered, I now bring to light the most exciting part about Rome: Total War: the mods.  There are so many good mods out there.  Note, these go well beyond a few stat changes and skins for units.  There are overhauls, historical mods, fantasy mods, etc.  Among the most prominent are Europa Barbarorum (a history buff's mod), Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ (a Roman buff's mod), Fourth Age: Total War (a Tolken buff's mod), and Terrae Expugnandae (a truly interesting mod).  There is even a Napoleonic era mod with actual units that use rifles.  The modding community is similar to that of Skyrim in that mods are available at many hubs dedicated to mods.  The ability to use mods in Rome just makes that dollar purchase that more worth it.   Rome: Total War is one of those quintessential games that needs to be played by everyone that has a PC.  It encompasses many aspects of strategy games and does not fail to deliever on the ancient Mediterranean theme.  You'll scream yells of excitement and aggravation as you play it.  The replayability is astronomical, especially with the use of mods.  I currently have a total of 544 hours of gameplay logged by Steam.  However, I've see numbers as high as 1000.  If you buy this game, I guarantee that you won't regret it.  The show that Rome puts on is worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Ah, Rome. I never played it at launch or for years after the fact, but it was always on my friends computer. Which he was of course one of those little wank-jobs that always showed off his♥♥♥♥♥♥but never shared it. No, about 2012 was really the first time I got to play R:TW, my first TW title being Medieval 2. Nowadays, people often say just get EB or any of the number of great mods. However, we're talking about Rome here, the base game as presented on Steam.First off, with this purchase you get both Rome 1 (which follows Roman history from before the first Punic War to the early Imperial age) and the expansion Barbarian Invasion (which follows, of course, the invasions of barbarian tribes during the decline of the Roman empire). You don't receive the expansion Alexander (the campaigns of Alexander the Great) but of all the Rome expansions- Alexander is often regarded as the poorest by both critics and fans.Rome 1 provides all the basics of a TW title. A campaign map where you conquer a part of the world. A skirmish game-mode where you fight the AI in a battle of choice. And Multiplayer (Now patched for steamworks as of 2014). Barbarian Invasion supplies the same package.Within the Campaign Map you choose one of three Roman Families at first. This is where I start to have some gripes with Rome. For one, you have to conquer the other factions to unlock them in the grand campaign. Two, even if you just edit the .ini files to unlock them, the campaign is heavily focused on Rome. They get the most units, the most mechanics, the most events, and the most progression. While it's perfectly possible to enjoy playing the underpowered Gauls, I find these other factions to be relatively abandoned by CA. Some factions feel relatively the same, such as the Gauls and Germans, with only minor unit variations to give some feel to them.  Also of note is that some factions are simply over-powered beyond conceivable belief. Units such as Rome's Urban Cohorts are just horrifying when placed against the AI. This can make Rome somewhat of a snooze-fest once the Marius Reforms activates and you start to get the best of the Roman crop. Other factions such as Gaul have laughably garbage infantry for the most part. While some argue historical accuracy, I find it harms the game balance and the ultimate enjoyment available. But a discussion on Rome's balance is way beyond the scope of this review, suffice it to say, Rome is unbalanced- but it rarely matters in single player.If however you only care for Rome, then RTW is for you. Each of the three families starts with an 'obvious' foe and paths of expansion. The Senate functions as a uniting force, rewarding you for following orders, showing disapproval when you fail. The whole game is built around your family as you grow both your empire and your influence. The game provides some great role-play as you follow the Senate's orders, checking to see if the masses or the patricians prefer you. As you progress, so will your power- inevitably enraging the Senate. It's moments like these where the campaign starts to shine. While I won't spoiler where that ultimately leads to, it justifies the slow start to the Imperial campaign.Speaking of the campaigning, the conquest of towns is fought on the battle map. Here you command your army, including your general if he's there, and engage the enemy. This is where the meat of the game is, and here where Total War makes its name. The battles are some of the fastest in the series, with units moving rapidly and viciously. Veteran units can stomp multiple newbie corps single-handedly. A single cavalry charge can lead to a rapid route. All this occurs to the excellent soundtrack of Jeff van Dyck and combat mechanics that (mostly) stand the test of time.I have a gripes here when compared to the later Total War games. For one, field battles (where units meet with no city or the like nearby) are unfortunately not too common in the later stages of the Campaign. This is due to the AI choosing the hide in cities. Due to this, you get to meet the siege battles of Rome- which are terrible. I'm not going to dance around this issue, siege battles are awful. The path finding of your units is all sorts of agony, and it only gets worse if you fight civilized nations that have large, built-up cities. You can have entire units enter into embarrassing formations where a handful of men are trying to take down a hoplite wall. It's funny, but it's hell. Siege battles can be ignored due to the great auto-resolve system Rome has, which can be used for field battles too.Unfortunately, I have issues with unit path-finding in general. Cavalry especially is very cumbersome compared to later titles. You will just have to get used with Cav occasionally ignoring your orders and charging head-long into spear-walls instead of between that wide-gap in the line. Also, units randomly charging other units instead of the ones you ordered them to is also common- this includes cav. It makes the control feel archaic, and from what I've researched it just seems to be a bug with the formations. It's annoying and often makes me just go towards Medieval 2 and download a Rome mod (EB2, I'm forever hyped). It isn't game-breaking since the AI is just...Meet CA's AI, from Rome to Rome 2 you're going to be playing with him. He's mentally insane, tuned seemingly for players that have no clue about formation tactics. The moment you figure out strategy, is the moment you realize that the AI is helplessly innocent, inept, incapable of learning, a terrible judge in terrain choice, a terrible flanker, and perhaps suicidal to boot. He's come in many different flavors- but really only modders seem capable of making him remotely competent. Increasing the difficulty will not make him smarter, only gives him a boost in unit stats. For a newbie, he's a good first opponent for casual player, but he won't teach you anything.What is not a flaw of the series is its presentation. Rome's simplistic art direction may have aged polygonal graphics but it still holds up relatively well, appearing distinguished and fluid despite being a game from 2004. It's a standard that's been kept by just about every title. The music, which I've only mentioned once, is some of the best in the series, bringing a lot of those aged graphics to life with broad stroke of tunes. Even the voice-acting has some charm, in the hammy sense.But we're not done, BI rounds out our package by being ♥♥♥♥ing painful. It's a campaign for barbarian lovers giving great variety to the barbars while still making Rome a fun faction. Notably a bit more balanced in the campaign the Western Rome campaign is one of the hardest challenges in TW history. It's meant only for series vets, even then it's infamous for the horror it gives. My personal opinion of it is that it's hard in the arbitrary sense, with unrest and religion stacking the deck on you. The AI isn't any smart notably (can land units by sea if the stars align). Most of the difficulty comes from rebellions, but the various barbarian tribes declaring war on you adds some fun. This campaign is historically inaccurate in it's portrayal of what troubled Rome. This is mostly due to the engine being incapable of modeling certain things. Historical inaccuracy is just a common thing in TW as it is- but I'm someone capable of ignoring this in favor of fun. BI besides the difficulty, is a neat addition to Rome and where I say barbarian lovers should go in lieu of the RTW.Still, RTW offers a great package for TW newbs. Introducing you to the series with a game that still holds up, with great modding potential. For the gripes I have, RTW is still a great game. If you have to choose a TW, go with an era that interests you most. All of them have pros and cons. Between Rome 1 and 2? You get a complete product with R1 that is fully patched and 'done'. No dlcs, no patches ruining your mods, same era.

												Perhaps one of the best games that I have played, ever. I personally perferred the multiplayer because I enjoyed just setting up an army and going head to head with other people. I have many great memories from these battles because the gameplay is really good. Rome: Total War was definitely a game ahead of its time and still is in my opinion a great game. Playing the multiplayer, you will accrue MANY memorable moments, and the recording feature at the end of each match allows you to relive those memories at another time. You will have battles where you become proud with your decisions and then you will have other games where you wonder "How in the world did I just do THAT bad?" This is a game in which you will feel as if you are the general on the battlefield: sometimes the one who would come home back to Rome with a Triumph, or the one utterly humiliated by some Barbarian people.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												This is quite possibly one of the best older games, besides stuff like Oblivion and Fallouts 1-3. It was released in 2004 or so, so the graphics arent all that impressive, but you can run it smoothly on anything save a toaster. Depending on the kind of toaster, it might even work. The gameplay is pretty much like the other Total War games: Manage cities, raise armies, do some diplomacy,some stabbing, wage some war. The brilliance comes in the tactical depth of the buildings, which is strange as you dont actually build them where you want, you just tell them to and it builds. Build a Temple of Ceres in your nice little town to grow it into a metropolis quickly, but beware of overgrowth. Essentially, enemy armies are not the only problem that can horribly screw up your faction. Speaking of factions, there are quite a few to play. the 3 Roman factions are playable from the start, but 9 or so others become available after you win with one of them. Winning is determined, not by killing off everyone else, but either A. capturing 15 settlements including Rome and outlasting/murdering a few factions, or B. holding 50 settlements and Rome. The few mods available are all really well made, with support up until at least last year. I forgot to mention the tactical battle mode, which is quite glorious. Strategy is key there. Send in the wardogs to rout the peasants, and mop up with cavalry, send spearmen to kill cavalry, etc. Theres a Rock-Paper-Scissors-Lizard-Spock kind of balance here.Anyways, its 10 bucks, includes 2 games, and has neigh infinite replayablity. Buy.
