content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This game was great 9 years ago and it is still great today. The campaign is very in-depth and it keeps you wanting to take just one more settlement before you save and quit. There's something very rewarding about building your measly little armies up from scratch and over time watching them become the dominant powerhouses that steamroll everything in their path. The diplomacy can be frustrating at times and the Senate will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. Always wanting you to blockade this port and take that city within X amount of moves. Then when you ask them for some help they're like, "Um, no." That's ok - when you're strong enough you can take them out too and run things how you like. Overall, it is by far one of the best RTS games ever and if you have that craving for war tactics like I do, this is the one for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												As a series, Total War has almost carved out its own sub-genre within the RTS genre. Each game effectively combines the depth of a grand strategy game, with the more direct strategic warfare of a real-time strategy game. The original Medieval and Shogun games were well received and popular, but Rome took the series to another level. The visuals saw a significant upgrade from the previous title, and in my opinion they still hold up pretty well even today. Perhaps the most revolutionary change in Rome: Total war is the era it is set in. Set during the expansion of the Roman Republic, there is a fantastic amount of variety in terms of factions. You start with the ability to play as one of three different Roman factions based on powerful patrician families, and you unlock new factions to play as by defeating them completely and removing them from the map. Personally, I don't like the separation of Rome into three different factions and would have preferred one faction, it feels like you are forced to expand into a particular direction; however this can be fixed by simply playing one of the mods that have a single Roman faction. As I said though, the variety provided by the factions is great. For example: the Romans focus on organisation and their poweful heavy infantry, but have to keep the senate and the other Roman families in mind; the Greeks have excellent phalanx infantry and skirmishers, but are vulnerable due to being spread out across the map; and the Parthians have their deadly combination of horse archers and cataphracts, but have limited expansion options due to being positioned at the eastern edge of the map. To contrast, Medieval II for example doesn't have this level of diversity simply because the fighting styles during that era were much more similar across the continent. The battles are extremely satisfying; as has come to be expected of the Total War series, though balancing between units is definitely an issue that seems to be persistent in the series. The campaign map gameplay has fantastic depth, so much so that you can often play for hours without having a battle and still be satisfied. The game's soundtrack is excellent; possibly the best in the series, and it really adds to the intensity of the battles.Though the vanilla game is amazing, the wealth of mods available to this game make it even better in various ways. There are a number of large scale total conversion mods but I have found that if you want the ultimate Rome: Total War experience you have two choices: Europa Barbarorum, or Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ II. Europa Barbarorum focuses on making sure everything is as authentic and historically accurate as possible,especially the barbarian factions that are somewhat neglected in the vanilla game. The campaign map is considerably larger, going as far south as southern Arabia, and as far east as India, and the roster of factions is extensive. However, the insane level of depth can be intimidating for some players. On the other hand, Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ II occupies the middle ground between the vanilla game and Europa Barbarorum. Whereas Europa Barbarorum pays particular attention to the barbarians, Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ focuses on fleshing out Rome itself. The mod adds a new system that adds a variety of Roman legions that each have a unique look and feel to them, and this really adds to the authenticity of the mod. There are plenty of new factions, and all the factions look and feel very unique. Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ II also looks much, much nicer, as the graphics have been improved a great deal on both the campaign map and battle maps; it looks about as good as Medieval II: Total War. Roma Sur♥♥♥♥♥♥ is only silghtly more complex than the vanilla game too, so it shouldn't be as intimidating as Europa Barbarorum. I wouldn't normally talk too much about mods in a review, but I honestly think that the optimal way to play this game is through one of these mods, as they improve almost everything.Even without modifications, Rome: Total War is a phenomenal game. If you enjoy real-time strategies but want a bit more depth to the strategy then this game should be just what you are looking for. 9/10Essential for Total War fans.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This game is... quoting the great words of Nacho, "es da best". The story, which consists of AI vs Player, in which it's map based domination, like Risk, and RT (Real-time) battles. So the units, and such are ACTUALLY moving, and responding to environment (rocks, trees, units, enemies and rivers). The story is relatively simple. Conquer what the game wants you to conquer (on fast campaign) or conquer like... 50? countries/cities on Long Campaign. The music in the game, it's alright. It's the kind of music you'd hear in a Roman Era genre. Orchestra-ish, theatrical-ish. AI, are based on difficulty. Hard difficulty? good luck. anything lower than that, is manageable. Multiplayer, being very close, to near death (no more people playing) but i constantly play this game with friends regardless. Take the time, to research this game, if wanting to buy. you might like Empire: Total War, or even the newer Total War. In all aspects the game is:AI: 8/10Story/singleplayer: 9/10Gameplay/battle: 10/10Menus/GUI: 10/10Multiplayer: 6/10 (not a lot of players, relatively buggy.Unit balance: 9/10Music: 8/10Graphics: 7/10Controls: 9/10Overall: 10/10 i really do enjoy this game, even though i'm not a big RTS fan.

content:

												My very first Total War game and it really hooked me.  One of my favorite things to do early game was just to create an entire army of peasants.  You haven't seen hell until you see over 3000 peasants trying to get through a gate all at once.  It was glorious and it made trained soldiers flee in terror just because of the sheer size of my host.  Unfortunately that tactic only works in the early game but it's fun to watch. I would build huge walls and watch as my archers tore apart the incoming troops.I would read about the buildings and units that I built and their historical context and I ended up learning a lot about it. I would deal with the "senate". I would master trade. It was all a surreal experience. I played this game so much that I scored a 100 on my europe geography test without any other use of materials. In short, buy this.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												I haven't played much Shogun 2, but compared to the rest of the series, this is my favorite TW game.  Everything seems to be in balance.  Take your favorite nation available and proceed to conquer the ancient world.  The strategic part of the game is not as skin deep as some would have you believe.  You need to be careful with your economy and the morale of the people to survive much.  The battles are much fun toplay, even though there are a couple of points where you can (but you shouldn't) abuse AI glitches.  The use of special characters is not as annoying as in the Medieval series, where it becomes an annoyance more than fun part of the game.  Great game and eagerly await for a sequel/remake of it some time in the future.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												I came, I saw, I conquered. Those words mean a lot in this game. When i saw this game in my local MVC shop before it closed down nearly 11 years ago. I wasn't sure if i would enjoy it. I loved games which involve empire building and controlling large armies on the battlefield like the good old AOE series. Although this game doesn't lead on the same path as AOE, it brings a lot more entertainment with empire building and controlling vast armies on battle map. This game, like a few others are the types of games that i could play for ages. They are my golden games to which i will never sell or never forget. Each faction has a strength or weakness, but it also depends on which units and buildings you create. It is up to you and you alone to survive. Its not a simple hit and run game where you can do anything you want and get away with it. Each choice, move and final act you make will to a certain point have an impact on your empire and your armies. You will never know who will betray you, attack you or ask for an alliance. The battlefields are more or less the same, once the battle begins, its fate, skill and intelligence that helps you win and leads you to world domination. Although the game will have its moments be it bugs, crashes or simple copy and paste. If you ever play the game on the hardest difficulty, the feeling of victory after an hour+ long battle is beyond satisfying. The battle music is perfect, the power and awesomeness before battle and the clash between your army and the computer AI is just as good. Many factions do have the same units and it can be rather annoying when facing the Roman's, but it can also be a wonderful challenge, but again, that all depends on the choices you make because one wrong more and that's it, everything could come to an end.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Let me start off by saying Rome is one of my favorite strategy games of all time. I also consider it being the game that got me into strategy/war games. However the Steam version is a very bad port. I can run the cd version perfectly fine on my computer but the Steam version lags considerably. The battles lag a little and the world map lags a considerable amount. I can run Empire and Napoleon on high for virtually no lag at all. Apparently the game used to run fine but CA added a patch that made the game into the state that it is now. CA seems to not be trying to fix the issue either. In conclusion, should you get Total War Rome? YES, but get the cd version instead. The game still gets a reccomendation for being a great game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Let me just start by saying I love strategy games. This game in particular was on sale for only $3 when I bought it; Lucky me. I can never get enough of this game. It makes my heart warm and happy as I send my men to annhilate the enemy army. Let's face it, if you choose the Julii campaign you're going to completely wreck the other houses. As you wave your flag across Europe, into the territories of what we now know of as France and Germany everyone will be kneeling down to pleasure you with their saliva and a certain body part. I must say, this game will consume your social life and teach you everything you need to know about the Roman times from 235 AD to at least 285 AD. Hell, you could even make the Western Empire in this game to your will. The gameplay of this game (especially during battles) is  SO ADDICTING that it's scary. I have played one session of this game for 24 hours straight out of my gameplay time. I would definately recommend buying this game, just be warned the game itself may give you extreme fatigue to where you'll pass out in the middle of a battle (trust me, I would know). Definately play the game without hurting your health. And just pirate the sequal to this game "Rome: Total War 2" since the original will always be the best one.

Posted: November 9, 2015
												Classic PC strategy game that still is amazing. The hours I have on this are off because I used to own this on disc, where I played numerous hours. I bought the Steam version due to the fact that GameSpy shut down. Now to the actual review.Whether you're a history buff, a Risk player, and/or a real time stategy game person, this game is for you. You can play historical battles, either online or offline. You can play the single player campaign very similar to Risk. However, the main attaction of this game are the real time battles, where you command armies in a battle to create your own fights, or to recreate/simulate real fights. It does require very good internet, especially considering the age of this game, which I would say is the only downside. Regardless, this game is a classic game that anyone should pick up to enjoy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												The first truly 3D Total War game.Gone is the Risk-style map, replaced with a completely new strategic map style, that will be continuosly improved on in future Total War games. Sadly, this also means that if you played later games from the series, you'll notice some missing/outdated functions. This is also, for a game based on real history, the least accurate game in the series. The Imperial Campaign begins in 270 BC. The Roman faction is divided into three, in a clumsy attempt to simulate the incoming Roman Civil War. And many factions have either fantastical units (ex: Arcanii) or are condensed (ex: all the Galic tribes are put together as one factions). It's also the most 'Hollywood history' styled game in the entire series - the Egyptain faction looks like straight out of 'The Ten Commandments', even though at that time in history they were more Greek than Egyptian.So why am I recommending this game?Because of the fantastical mod support, that fixes and adds anything you can imagine. This game, and M2TW, are the most mod friendly Total War games. The mod community around them is why people return to play these games even today.Along with the original Rome: Total War, this collection also includes Barbarian Invasion, an expansion that moves the date to late antiquity, and this time it is a much more historically faithful representation of the Great Migrations period.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												This game was a classic, yet if you do not already own it, it is now more trouble than it is worth.  As someone who has put many hours into this game (owning it on CD long before I bought it again for steam) I have to say its many bugs combined with its age mean it no longer the game it once was.You may boot it up and find yourself enjoying it, only to discover any one of many game breaking bugs.  These bugs are older than many small children and most have no known solution.  I myself have had trouble with CTDs upon ending my turn, graphical glitches, freezes deep into epic battles and others.  The one that sent me over the edge involved a bug where you can not attack your enemies but they can attack you.  It happens after a special event late in the game and there is no remedy.While this game is a classic and was great in its time, it has not kept up with software advancements and I assume the problems will only pile up over time.  Unless your an anthropologist interested in old relics, don't bother with this game any longer.  I say this as a fan, rest in peace old friend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												One of the best games of all time. If you like strategy, buy the game. If you like the Roman period, buy the game. If you like reliving classics, buy the game. If you like watching sizzling bacon terrify elephants, buy the game. Despite what my steam log says I played this game way before steam was a thing (as many other people have) and I am glad it hasn't dug out the records for hours played because I would realise how much of my time I could have spent doing something more useful. It's certainly not wasted time though as almost no other game can recreate the fun of fighting over a stupid bridge in the middle of Germany or running around the map trying to catch skirmishers on multiplayer. Gameplay is still solid after 11 years, graphics aren't great but they do the job in a better way later titles have, you make your own story and the multiplayer is still fun. The community is almost gone and I miss the days were multiple clan battle were seen on the friendly server. Overall though I r8 M80/10 because the game is insanely good. Although newer systems do drop framerate a bit and I have had to have worse settings than my old computer. Even so the game is still one of the top TW and strategy titles to date. Buy this game.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Of course I am going to sound biased when I say this but this honestly is one of the best, if not, THEE BEST strategy game ever made. Bought this when I was a prepubescent child and I made so many memories with it then and still do today. Gameplay is fantastic, both campaign and RTS. And the music to this day still gives me these chills and adrenaline rushes when playing a battle. It's very unfortunate that its successor Rome 2 didn't live up to how brilliant the first one was. Especially considering this most likely is the best of all the Total Wars with Shogun 2 being a very close exception. Not to mention it pretty much laid out the gameplay formula for every Total War game ever since (look up its predecessors and their gameplay and you’ll understand lol). It deserves the best because it is, well, the best! And yeah, the game is over a decade old but that hasn’t stopped me from ever playing it. And if you can find a way to still play multiplayer games with friends. Do it. It’s ridiculously fun.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Let me start off by saying Rome is one of my favorite strategy games of all time. I also consider it being the game that got me into strategy/war games. However the Steam version is a very bad port. I can run the cd version perfectly fine on my computer but the Steam version lags considerably. The battles lag a little and the world map lags a considerable amount. I can run Empire and Napoleon on high for virtually no lag at all. Apparently the game used to run fine but CA added a patch that made the game into the state that it is now. CA seems to not be trying to fix the issue either. In conclusion, should you get Total War Rome? YES, but get the cd version instead. The game still gets a reccomendation for being a great game.

												So last night....I stayed up until midnight, preparing to attack Rome, three full stack armies, two of them coming from the North, full of Urban Cohorts and the most elite troops I could get. One coming from the sea to the west, a fodder army of lesser troops. The turn before I plan on attack, SPQR denounces mine and the other three houses. Instant Civil War, four or five of my settlements beseiged by the other two houses, but I press on. First, my fodder army lands, 2-3k of my troops against two full stacks of SPQR elite troops, some 5-6k. I manage 681 kills to their complete annihlation of my army. SPQR forces have HUGE buffs. But it works, one of their armies is too far away from their capital to provide back up, so I lay siege. As soon as my towers are built, I assault the city. Walls so large they fill the entire screen, my onagers unable to penetrate them. The SPQR has less than a thousand men garrisoned in the city, but my reinforcements are delayed, they may not make it to the battle. With the enemies army marching at us from the other side of the city I quickly charge the walls. Sending my top units up the towers, I lose a thousand men, just trying to take the walls that less than four hundred defended. I rush a company of men to the other gate, to prevent enemy reinforcements from entering the city, they get there just in time. Now they must use my siege towers, I turn my onagers against them, destroying my own siege towers. But I haven't the ammo, one remains. With my battered and half killed army, I march to the city center, leaving only one unit back to defend the walls, along with my archers positioned along the enemy's approach. Half of my forces retreat from the city center as soon as combat ensues. The other half fighting bravely, but slowly losing. The enemy army reaching my tower, and then, reinforcements, my own. Finally arrived, striking the enemy in the back as they try to clamber up their own walls. I send the calvary and some infantry around to the side gate, attacking the city center from behind. I lose near on a thousand more men fighting the contingent of several hundred in the center, but I take it. Now I must hold it. With the enemy army at my back, attacking the walls my men so valiantly took. My second army charging at them, forcing them up against the walls, ballista's and arrows raining down on them. They begin to break, but so do my men. The might of the SPQR is undeniable, their armor thicker, weapons sharper. Sending the calvary out of the side gate, hitting them in their flank, finally the break. And the city is mine. The SPQR is destroyed, but the war has just begun, now the house Julii must reign supreme over the other two houses, they must be dealt with and swiftly. And with the Britons to my north, I know my victory of Rome will be a spec in comparison to the battles that I must fight to be declared ruler of the Roman Empire, and the world!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												I have sunk over 200 hours of my life into this game, and guess what? Every last one was enjoyable. RTW is my favorite title by Creative Assembly, and my favorite real time strategy game as a direct result. The main thing most people sink hours into is the Imperial Campaign, which can last an upwards of 20 hours per campaign if drawn out. Your goal is simple, conquer 50 territories in the known world, and of course, Rome. The most focus in this mode has obviously been given to the Romans, as they have unique mechanics in the campaign, such as the ever hostile senate, the Civil War, the reforms of Gaius Marius, and so on. This isnt to say the other possible factions are any less far to play, far from it in fact. Playing as Carthage, you have access to mighty war elephants, the Greeks get their Spartans, the Germanians get Bezerkers, everyone has a unique element that mixes up gameplay in a way that forces you to adapt different strategy for each campaign. The AI for battles can either be brilliant, or mind numbingly awful, depending upon the difficulty you set it to. However if you want a real challenge, you are going to have to take your skills online. Despite being a very old title, there still is a good chunk of people playing this online. Most of them are experienced veterans, so dont be too upset if they wipe the floor with you the first couple of battles. The nostalgia runs deep in this game, and for those of you who have never played a Total War game, its probably the best game you can start with. It was GOTY worthy when it came out back then, and compared to RTW2, its a gem every collector should have in their library.

It's extremely addictive, I mean a whole day can pass by without you doing much of anything, because there's so many things to capture your attention, and a threat around every corner.  It's usually pretty cheap these days, so if you were ever remotely interested in this type of game, I'd highly recommend trying it out.

												In 2005, aside from Morrowind there couldn't have been a better game for my to pour hours of my life into. I had just finished a fairly shallow, but interesting intro Roman History course, and I was home for the summer, jobless. My campaigns and expeditions really drew me in, especially the focus on individual characters. Watching as a 16 year old noble started an insane mercenary fueled campaign and grew into a competent commander and ruler was immensely satisfying.The systems in the game all fit together well and provide a fun, if not entirely historically accurate grand strategy game. 10 war elephants out of ten for me.

												5 Hours in:After playing this game for a few hours, I really enjoy it. As someone who really enjoyed Sid Meier's Civilization V, the campaign is really enjoyable. Definately get this game if you liked Civ V or enjoy a good strategy game.15 Hours in:Just beat 7 Armies of Gauls with my one army of Selucid warriors. [proof http://imgur.com/aznIG1d] I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.30 Hours in:The campagin is even more fun now that I've put a few hours into it. The different factions with different units make things much more interesting and the Senate's missions really help drive objectives. The campaign really flows and feels like a living civilization. I found myself so deeply involved with this game that 2 hours passed within what felt like 20 minutes.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												Don't even think about it; this title is a definite buy.  This was my first RTS, although it is a mix of RTS or Turn-Based, the battles that take place are RTS.  This is my first Total war game ever, so I might not know everything about the franchise, but what i've experienced in the time i've played is amazing.  The graphics are definitely not going to blow you away in todays standards, but back when this was released was very impressive, in my gameplay there was about 2,000 people on the battlefield at once.  Don't get me wrong this game is not perfect, but is pretty close. For example, your troops get stuck way too many times. Also your troops run scared even though you may outnumber them 8:1 and you are dominating them. Those minor errors do not in fact damage the game in any way.  I do have one major problem since this game came out so long ago, my Nvidia can't automatically optimize it for me so it goes kind of slow for me, but maybe that is just me. Bought this on the Sega/Total War sale 10/10

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												Though I may have few hours on the steam version of Rome, don't be decieved. I have played this game for AT LEAST 100 hours on the disc version. That said, the review. This game is an extremely fun game that can run on just about any budget modern computer on some of its best settings (+ any graphical mods you want to get if your card can run them). It's relatively simple and easy to learn, yet intuitive and the differences are clear when comparing one who is good at the game to one who isnt. The single player Imperial Campaign is a really fun interesting way of playing if you have the time to invest in to it, however there are just quick battles instead if that is what you are looking for. There are challenging historical battles you can do which is also difficult and interesting. And there is also multiplayer if you are looking for that too.

												Nothing beats a classic, and Rome: Total War is a classic.  I'm sure there were games that predated it (the original Medieval Total War, right?), but Rome is probably a solid place to start.For the time it came out and its place so early in the franchise, you can't fault it much.  It has all the staples that would appear in the other installations in the franchise, and the balance of story, graphics, and controls make it a fun experience that isn't terribly hard to learn.Anyone who is a fan of tactical games, strategy games, historical games, or even just enjoys playing God for a tiny nation of soldiers should enjoy this game.
